ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
This species is present in many protected areas, including Natura 2000 sites, across its range. It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in many countries and is recorded on a number of national and sub-national Red Data books and lists. It is considered Critically Endangered in Great Britain (Foster et al. 2021), Vulnerable in Czechia (Chobot and Nemec 2017), Austria (Gollmann 2007), Slovenia (Anonymous 2010), Albania (Anonymous 2013), Romania (Botnariuc and Tatole 2005), Near Threatened in France (UICN France et al. 2015), Switzerland (Schmidt and Zumbach 2005), Hungary (Halpern et al. 2019), Data Deficient in Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015). In parts of the species' range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

The species has been reintroduced to the UK. Monitoring is required for this species, and conservation action to protect sites and improve habitat condition are required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: It is present in deciduous and mixed forests, forest steppe, steppe, bushlands (e.g. riparian alder groves), meadows, fields and fens. It may often be found in shallow stagnant waterbodies (usually without fish) such as lakes, ponds, marshes, moors, swamps, large puddles, clay and gravel pits, ditches, and small ponds, often covered with dense herbaceous vegetation (Speybroeck et al. 2016). The species breeds in these wetlands but may be found hibernating away from waterbodies. It is not very adaptable but can occur in slightly modified habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Although this species is reported to be declining over much of its European range (Gasc et al. 1997), it remains widespread and common in Poland, the Baltic Republics, Moldova, Russia and Ukraine. According to Speybroeck et al. (2016), the range of P. lessonae largely overlap with the P. kl. esculentus range. "lessonae-only" areas have been recorded in Sweden, Norway, partly Finland, Belarus, Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and Russia, and, on the south of distribution area, in Corsica and in northern parts of Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is distributed over much of Europe, ranging as far east as Bashkortostan Republic in Russia. It is absent from the Iberian Peninsula (except for introductions to Spain), from much of Scandinavia and from the most of the Balkans (Lukanov et al. 2013, Tzankov and Popgeorgiev 2015, Speybroeck et al. 2016). There are two isolated subpopulations - one near Oslo (Norway) and Uppland (Sweden) north of Stockholm. It is native but formerly extirpated to the British Isles, but has been reintroduced to a single site in East Anglia (Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Trust) from Sweden. The species has recently been recorded from the Volgograd region in Russia (Lada et al. 2016), and, the first country records, from Bulgaria along the Danube River in the northern part of the country (Lukanov et al. 2017). It might occur up to 1,550 m asl in southern parts of its range.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 Member States in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is threatened by habitat loss through agricultural intensification and urbanisation, channelisation of waterbodies, drainage and pollution of wetlands, and the introduction of predatory fishes to breeding sites. It is additionally threatened by afforestation (in northern parts of the range) and competition with the larger sympatric P. ridibundus. Road mortality impacts across the range of the species.

Destruction of naturally occurring metapopulation systems through lack of connectivity increases local population extinction rates (Sjorgen-Gulve, 2020).

The frog-leg trade and high levels of pollution led to significant declines in subpopulations within countries of former Yugoslavia, particularly in Serbia and Montenegro (Džukić et al. 1996, Ljubisavljević et al. 2003); it is not clear to what extent intentional harvest continues, but unintentional collection may persist.

The species is also susceptible to pathogens; Stupar et al. (2020) recently discovered a case of the presence of water mould Aphanomyces sp. on the skin of Pool Frogs in Serbia.

Introduced fish Perccottus glenii strongly prey on tadpoles of this species causing a strong decline in the number of local populations in Russia (Reshetnikov 2001).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: They were collected for human consumption within the former Yugoslavia and, after, in Serbia and Montenegro (Džukić et al. 1996, Ljubisavljević et al. 2003). Although somewhat smaller in size than edible and marsh frogs, the pool frog also could be harvested in syntopic areas with these two, if there is no adequate taxonomic screening.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: This species occurs in Doñana, Islas Atlánticas de Galicia, Sierra Nevada and Cabañeros National Parks, all in Spain. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and is also listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and is protected by national legislation in Spain and listed in the Spanish national Red Data Book.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally found within or in the direct vicinity of water (with surrounding dense vegetation), including still waters, swamps, mountain streams, drinking troughs and sometimes-brackish waters. The terrestrial habitats of the species occur on granite and other metamorphic rocks, and include sandy areas close to the sea, open areas, meadows, thickets, gulleys and woodland edges. They also inhabit cork-oak savannas (Dias et al. 2013). The species breeds, and larval development takes place, within shallow permanent or temporary waterbodies. It is often present in slightly modified areas, such as traditional farmland.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: In Spain, it is abundant over much of its range (with the exception of the north and northeastern subpopulations), while in Portugal the species can be locally abundant in fragmented subpopulations. It is likely that isolated populations have recently become extinct along the Mediterranean coast. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: The species is endemic to the Iberian Peninsula (Portugal and most of western Spain), where it is found at altitudes ranging from sea level to 1,940 m asl (Piedrahita, Spain). Following genetic analysis, it is now also known from southern, eastern and northeastern Spain due to the synonymy of Discoglossus jeanneae (Dufresnes et al. 2020), and occurs up to 2,050 m asl.
RedListRationale.value: This species is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The main threats to this species are the general intensification of agriculture, infrastructure development, the contamination of aquatic habitats, and the introduction of predatory fishes and crustaceans (especially the Louisiana Crayfish Procambarus clarkii) through much of its range. Desertification is a threat to the species in the more arid parts of its range such as southern Portugal. Additionally, hydroelectric projects are leading to habitat loss in parts of Portugal. However, overall this species is probably not seriously threatened at present. Although previous assessment found no serious threat for this species, variation in climatic conditions could have a major role in the abundance of breeding adults, as was suggested in study of Olarte et al. (2020).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Reserva Ornitologica de Mindelo in northern Portugal.

Conservation Needed
Conservation of terrestrial and aquatic habitats and control of invasive species is required (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. May 2020).

Research Needed
This species' distribution limit with Pelodytes ibericus needs to be worked out in more detail in some areas (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. May 2020). There is also very limited information about its life history, demography and patterns of population abundance and connectivity which requires more research (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. May 2020).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found mostly in temporary ponds in traditional farmland (Dufresnes 2019), coastal dunes, open Quercus woodland (“dehesas”), cultivated areas (margins of rice plantations). It is reported to be sensitive to changes in traditional agricultural practices and the introduction of exotic predatory species (Beja and Alcazar 2003, Cruz et al. 2008). Breeding takes place in mainly temporal ponds and streams, similar to Pelodytes punctatus and P. ibericus (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. May 2020).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is generally not very abundant (Beja and Alcazar 2003; I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. 2024), although there may some abundant populations. Local extinctions in Reserva Natural de Paul do Boquilobo in central Portugal, associated with the introduction of the Red Swamp Crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) have been reported in the past (Cruz et al. 2008). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is restricted to the Atlantic coast of Portugal, between 0-900 m asl (Malkmus 2004, Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017). It is not known from adjacent parts of Spain.
RedListRationale.value: The Lusitanian Parsley Frog (Pelodytes atlanticus) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to the Atlantic coast of mainland Portugal. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, although localised declines have been reported.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Despite occurring in traditional farmland habitats, threats to this species are the result of habitat alteration, fragmentation and loss caused by the intensification of agriculture, and the introduction of exotic species such as Procambarus clarkii (Beja and Alcazar 2003; I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. May 2020).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas including Doñana and Cabañeros National Parks in Spain. In Portugal it is present in Peneda-Gerês National Park, where the subpopulation of Carris Lake has been impacted by disease. It is listed on Annex III of the Bern Convention and on Annex V of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It was recorded in the national Red Data Book of Spain (Pleguezuelos et al. 2002), and several regional Red Data Books. The species has been bred ex situ.

Conservation Actions Needed
Control of invasive species and disease

Research Needed
Further research into the impacts of disease on this species is needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species inhabits a wide variety of temporary and permanent waterbodies (pools, streams, ditches, irrigation canals etc.). The terrestrial habitats of the species include forests, Mediterranean-type scrub, agricultural areas, rocky areas, coastal marshes, gardens and urban parks. It is able to tolerate some habitat disturbance, and it breeds in various aquatic habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is generally widespread and common over much of the Iberian Peninsula (Martínez-Solano et al. 2003), while subpopulations in France are reported to be scarce and dispersed (Gasc et al. 1997). Despite sampling efforts, this species has not be recorded in 29.8% of its range in Spain since before 1999 (I. Martínez-Solano and P. Hernández Sastre pers. comm. April 2020). Due to ongoing local decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and harvesting of individuals for food, the population is suspected to be locally decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is found in southern France and across the whole of the Iberian Peninsula (Pleguezuelos 1997, Arnold 2003). It occurs from sea level up to 2,380 m asl (in the Sierra Nevada, Spain; Fernández-Cardenete et al. 2000).

The species has been introduced to the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands (Spain), to Madeira and the Azores (Portugal; the distribution in the Azores requires further details and is not mapped here), and to two sites in the United Kingdom (Sheppey, Kent and Newdigate, Surrey).
RedListRationale.value: Perez's Frog (Pelophylax perezi) is endemic to Europe. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
There are generally no major threats to this widespread species. Localised threats include changes in habitat through the loss of traditional agricultural methods, drainage or pollution of wetlands, collection of individuals for human consumption, and hybridisation with introduced farmed European ranids (P. esculentus complex).

Mortality of the species through disease (iridovirus) has been recorded in Carris Lake, Peneda-Gerês National Park, Portugal. The disease might be non-native and have been transferred to the lake by an introduced predatory fish (Lepomis gibbosus). Predation by L. gibbosus and other introduced predatory fish species occurs but is probably not a threat, and it is not greatly threatened in Portugal by the expansion of non-native predatory crayfish (P. Beja pers. comm.), including Procambarus clarkii (). In France, it is being displaced within some of its range by the introduced species Pelophylax ridibundus.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is utilised for subsistence.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and on Annexes II and IV of the EU Habitats Directive. It is recorded in the National Red Lists and is protected by national legislation in Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Montenegro. In Slovenia, the subterranean habitat of the species is also protected by national legislation, and much of the range of this species is within Natura 2000 or other protected areas (Hudoklin 2011). In Italy and Croatia parts of its range are also included in Natura 2000 (Koller et al. 2019). The subspecies Proteus anguinus parkelj is particularly in need of protection, as its habitat is limited to only a few karst springs in connection with subterranean networks in a very small geographic area. Rehabilitation centres for veterinary treatment of injured or ill specimens are organised in Slovenia and Croatia, and at the Trebišnjica River Basin in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Aljančič et al. 2016, Lewarne 2018, Koller et al. 2019).

Conservation Needed
Once the identity of the different conservation units is confirmed, they are likely to have highly restricted ranges, are likely to be threatened and will require specific conservation actions (K. Poboljsaj pers. comm. September 2019). Urgent action is needed particularly to reduce pollution in the habitat of subspecies P. a. parkelj (G. Aljančič, P. Trontelj, V. Zakšek and K. Poboljsaj pers. comm. December 2019) and, generally, to remove aquatic invasive species. There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Further taxonomic work is required to confirm the identity of the different conservation units.Ecological research on lifespan and population needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The species occurs in karstic subterranean aquatic systems formed in limestone and dolomite rocks. It inhabits subterranean karstic habitats up to 1500 m vertical depth (dry cave systems with water streams at the bottom) and up to -113 depth of water column, withstanding water pressure of up to 12 atmospheres (Kovač-Konrad and Koller 2017). Many of the caves that the species occurs in are connected to rivers that run above ground for the first 50–100 km and then disappear into the ground. Subpopulations may be found close to the surface or as much as 300 m underground depending on the thickness of the karstic formation. It may also be found at cave entrances or washed-out of caves after episodes of high rainfall and flooding (Aljančič et al. 2014b).

The water temperature of the habitat ranges from about 5°C to 15°C, which is also the approximate extent of annual fluctuations. Proteus anguinus parkelj is found in warmer surface waters and some subpopulations of the nominal subspecies were found in such conditions as well. Animals feed on detritus and endemic cave invertebrates and hide in crevices or bottom sediment when disturbed, and are well adapted to cave life (e.g. Briegleb 1962, Aljančič et al. 1993, Bulog 2006, Balázs et al. 2015, Zakšek et al. 2017, Gorički et al. 2019). As it is very difficult to study the species in its natural subterranean habitat, most ecological data comes from cave laboratories (Briegleb 1962, Parzefall et al. 1980, Hervant et al. 2000). In captivity, they become sexually mature at 15 years of age and reproduce on average only every 12 years, while their lifespan can exceed 100 years (Voituron et al. 2011). Females lay up to 70 eggs on the undersides of stones (Briegleb 1962, Juberthie et al. 1996), and in some cases, the eggs are retained within the body and two fully formed young are produced.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
Due to its inaccessible habitat, few data are available on the abundance of this species (Briegleb 1962, Trontelj and Zakšek 2016), but according to the number of documented sites (Sket 1997, Koller et al. 2019), it is apparently most common in Slovenia and Croatia. A study by Vörös et al. (2019) of four cave systems in Croatia showed the highest population density of 7–11.45 individuals/10 m2 of cave, and the lowest of 0.45–1.08 individuals/10 m2 of cave.

A decline in the number of sites and individuals has been reported for the subpopulations of Goriza (Italy), Potojna (Slovenia) (Gasc et al. 1997), Dolenjska and Bela Krajina (Slovenia) (Hudoklin 2011) and Croatia (Jelić et al. 2012). In Herzegovina, the subpopulation from the subterranean Trebišnjica River has severely declined in the past (Milanović 1990). Local subpopulations have gone extinct in the region of Kočevje (Slovenia) (Sket 1997). The number of individuals of the subspecies P. a. parkelj is considered very low due to its extremely narrow range, documented at no more than 3 km2 (Gorički et al. 2017).

More than half (> 50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal. The population is therefore considered to be severely fragmented. Due to ongoing decline in its AOO and the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to the European region, where it is restricted to subterranean aquatic habitats within the Dinaric Karst region of the Balkans, ranging from southern Slovenia and just across the border into adjoining northeastern Italy, through disjunct areas of western Croatia, and western Bosnia and Herzegovina, reaching the Trebišnjica River Basin in the south (e.g. Sket 1997, Jablonski et al. 2012, Koller et al. 2019, Kostanjšek et al. 2022). Environmental DNA of the species was also detected in western Montenegro (not mapped) (Aljančič et al. 2014a, Gorički et al. 2017), while the closest confirmed localities lie just across the border in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Its global AOO is 1,132 km2 and the global EOO is 55,470 km2.

Outside its natural range, the species has been introduced and naturalised in the subterranean basin of the Valstagna Caves near Oliero in northeastern Italy, which was populated from the Postojna-Planina Cave system in Slovenia in 1822 (Bressi and Dolce 2006). Captive subpopulations are maintained at the Subterranean Laboratory CNRS Moulis (France) and the Tular Cave Laboratory (Slovenia), and in the show caves, Postojna Caves (Slovenia), Hermannshöhle (Germany), Grotte de Choranche (France) and Baredine (Croatia).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)

This species is listed as Vulnerable because its area of occupancy (AOO) is 1,132 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in its AOO, the extent and quality of its habitat, and the number of mature individuals.

In the EU27 member states the species is also assessed as VU B2ab(ii,iii,v), as its AOO is less than 1,132 km2, but larger than 500 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in its AOO, the extent and quality of its habitat, and the number of mature individuals.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The main threat to this species is increasing pollution of groundwater in karst landscapes, coming from intensive agriculture (overuse of fertilisers and phyto-pharmaceuticals), urbanisation (non-functioning sewage and waste treatment, public landfills and illegal dumping in caves or permeable karst terrain), traffic and industry (Kostanjšek et al. 2022).

In Croatia, invasive fish introduction present major threat (Jelić et al. 2012)

In Slovenia, more attention is put on increased nitrates in groundwater (Năpăruş-Aljančič 2017, Kolar 2018) and emerging threats from pathogens (Kostanjšek et al. 2017). Past ecological incidents are still a considerable source of pollution; high accumulation of heavy metals and PCB were detected in tissues of selected subpopulations in Slovenia (Bulog et al. 2002, Pezdirc et al. 2011). Destruction of habitat, such as extensive hydrotechnical works for hydroelectric power stations remains a particularly severe threat in Bosnia and Herzegovina (Čučković 1983, Lewarne 1999) and in Croatia (Jelić et al. 2012). Considerable threat comes from changes to the forested and pastoral land above the subterranean cave systems, including intensive agriculture - excessive groundwater pumping for irrigation in agriculture, salinisation of karst springs and fish farming (Ozimec 2011, Aljančič et al. 2014a). These changes have a direct influence on the quality and extent of the groundwater habitat, which also represents the only reliable source of drinking water in the karst for the Western Balkans. Significant threats to this species could also arise through tourism – especially sport diving in the caves (see in Balázs and Lewarne 2017). The species is highly dependent on clean water, and local subpopulations in the wild are therefore very susceptible to pollution and fungal infections other than Bsal (e.g. Lukac et al. 2015, Bizjak-Mali et al. 2018). Additionally, climate change is expected to dramatically increase the timing, frequency and magnitude of periodical floods, and the ability of Proteus to cope with environmental changes will be apparently reduced (Aljančič et al. 2014). There is some occasional illegal collection of the species for the pet trade.
In Italy and Slovenia, introduced freshwater species may present major threat in the future.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal demonstrate low-level infection and subsequent disease for this species (Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). It is thought that wild subpopulations would have some resistance to Bsal and it is not considered to be a major threat. Extinction risk modeling demonstrates that this species will not be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are some anecdotes about this species being found in the pet trade, but it is not considered a major threat.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in Peneda-Gerês Parque Nacional in Portugal, and Parque Naturales Fragas do Eume, Corrubedo, Monte Aloia, O Invernadeiro, Serra do Xurés, Enciña da Lastra, Gorbea and Izki in Spain, as well as in Parque Nacional Sierra de Guadarrama in central Spain. It is also protected by national legislation and listed in the national Red Data Book as Vulnerable. This species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It has been successfully reintroduced in a small area of the Parque Nacional Guadarrama (Spain, Madrid) following a rearing in captivity program and an eradication program of introduced salmonids (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection and population monitoring are required. Eradication of invasive fish species is necessary in some areas (Bosch et al. 2006, 2019).

Research Needed
Further research is needed to fully understand the subpopulation declines in Spain.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is an aquatic species usually found in shady habitats (with abundant vegetation) close to rivers, streams, lakes and marshes. In Portugal, it typically inhabits mountainous areas, next to streams of clean water, with rocky substrate and abundant vegetation on the banks (Teixeira 2008). The main habitats in north-western Spain and northern Portugal are the shores of clear streams, springs and small rivers with running water, especially if they have riverside forest on their banks (Galán 1982). The species' terrestrial habitats include woods, moors, meadows and areas of low scrub. In the north of its range, it can occur down to sea level along slower-flowing rivers. In central Spain it is mostly a montane species, occurring up to >2,000 m asl (Lizana et al. 1990, Esteban and Sanchiz 2000). Breeding and larval development takes place within various shallow stagnant water bodies, as well as in the streams and rivers where adults live. Their generation length is thought to be two to three years (Esteban and Sanchiz 2000).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
The species is reasonably common in northern Portugal and north-western Spain. Subpopulations in Extremadura (Spain) are fragmented and declining very seriously (Pleguezuelos et al. 2002, Fernández Ortin 2013). Local declines have been reported in Galicia (Galán 2006), where the species is still abundant and widespread. There is also evidence of subpopulation declines in the Sierra de Guadarrama (Madrid, Spain) due to the combined effects of habitat degradation and loss, introduced species, infectious disease and climate change (SCV 2001, Martínez-Solano 2006, Martínez-Solano et al. 2003, Bosch et al. 2006, 2018, 2019; Polo-Cavia et al. 2017), and also in the Basque Country (Arrayago et al. 2018).

It is believed that the population of this species has declined by at least 30% in the last ten years (which is the longer time period than three generation lengths; I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. June 2020).

In higher elevation subpopulations the introduction of fish species (especially salmonids) seems to contribute more significantly to population decline than pathogens (Bosch et al. 2006, 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to central and northern Portugal (Paulo 1997, Godinho et al. 1999, Malkmus 2004) and north-western and central Spain (Galán 1989, Mensi et al. 1992, Pleguezuelos 1997, Arano et al. 1993, Gasc et al. 1997, Galán 1999, Pleguezuelos et al. 2002, Arnold 2003). It mostly occurs from sea level along the Atlantic coast up to 2,425 m asl in montane areas (such as the Sierra de Béjar, central Spain). Fragmented subpopulations of this species are present in Cantabria (Ruiz Elizalde 2018, 2021), the Basque Country (Arrayago et al. 2010, Gosá et al. 2018), the Central System Mountains (García-París and Martín 1987), Extremadura in Spain (Fernández Ortín 2013) and Marinha Grande and Serra de São Mamede in Portugal. In Portugal, the Iberian Frog is absent along an extensive strip along the Spanish border, including the Mirandês Plateau (with the exception of a small isolate in the Serra de Bornes), most of the upper Douro, Côa and Águeda Internacional valleys and the area south of the Serra da Malcata, Gardunha and Alvelos. The species also has a dispersed distribution along the coastal strip south of Espinho, with the population isolate of S. Pedro de Moel as the limit of distribution on the coast. South of the Tagus River, it occurs only in the Serra de S. Mamede (Teixeira 2008).
RedListRationale.value: The Iberian Frog (Rana iberica) is endemic to the Iberian Peninsula, Europe. It is assessed as Vulnerable because of a population decline, estimated to be 30% over the past 10 years, inferred from the combined impact of habitat loss and degradation, and the effects of introduced species, infectious diseases and climate change.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Threats to this species include pressure from tourism development (Rodríguez Prieto and Fernandez Juricic 2005), urbanisation of its lowland range, habitat loss through intensification of agriculture, deforestation and re-afforestation with non-native monocultures, alteration of streams and stream banks resulting from forest exploitation, desertification in southern Portugal, infectious diseases (von Essen et al. 2020 found Ranavirus infection in this species), climate change, and habitat loss through hydroelectric projects.

Introduced alien species also impact the species through predation. These include non-native crayfishes (Procambarus clarkii and Pacifastacus leniusculus), native and non-native predatory fishes (especially salmonids; Bosch et al. 2006, 2019), and possibly mammals such as American Mink Neovison vison (García-Díaz et al. 2013).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in several protected areas across its range. It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention, and is listed on Annex II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in Italy, Switzerland, Croatia and Slovenia, and has been recorded in a number of national and Red Data books and lists. This species is Endangered in Slovenia (Anonymous 2010) and Croatia (Jelić et al. 2012), and as Vulnerable in Italy (Rondinini et al. 2022) and Switzerland (Schmidt et al. 2023).

Conservation Needed
Improved management of the protected areas this species occurs in is required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The original habitat of this species is semi-hygrophilous forest; in secondary habitats, it is associated with humid deciduous wooded areas, typically situated alongside small streams, rivers, or lakes, with rich vegetation. It is present in poplar plantations with thick understorey and occasionally meadows (Arnold 2003, Barbieri and Mazzotti 2006). It hibernates on land, where it may occur up to a kilometer from water (Arnold 2003). The species breeds in permanent and temporary water in wooded areas, sometimes including slow-moving rivers, that generally have abundant aquatic vegetation (Barbieri and Mazzotti 2006). However, in Slovenia and Croatia, they prefer to breed in small streams only containing leaves and submerged branches (K. Poboljšaj pers. comm. December 2019). It can occur in anthropogenic habitats such as agricultural irrigation ditches, but only if these are close to forest remnants for over-wintering (T. Garner. pers. comm.).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is relatively abundant along some northern tributaries of the Po River, with a few sites existing along southern tributaries. It is occasional and localised in north-western Italy being more common in north-eastern areas. Some of the breeding sites in Switzerland can contain hundreds of individuals and long time series data for all subpopulations shows that the population is stable (KARCH 2014). Subpopulations of the species are generally larger in the eastern parts of its range and population genetic diversity decreases sharply from east to west by a factor of three (subpopulations located in the western part of the distribution have severely reduced genetic diversity as measured at microsatellite loci, while subpopulations located in the east do not (T. Garner pers. comm.). A first attempt at assessing the minimal population size in Slovenia resulted in an estimate of more than 50,000 adults (Cipot et al. 2015). Results of continental-scale determinants showed negative population trends for this species (Falaschi et al. 2019).

The population is considered to be severely fragmented with more than half (> 50%) of the individuals existing in small and isolated patches (K. Poboljšaj pers. comm. July 2020). Furthermore, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the effects of invasive species, the population is inferred to be decreasing. Between 2011-2019, a decline of 14% of the subpopulation in Lambro River Basin in Lombardy, Italy occurred due to the combined effects of habitat loss and invasive crayfish (R. Manenti pers. comm. to F. Ficetola July 2020).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This European endemic species occurs from the lowlands of the Padano Venetian plain of northern Italy and southern Switzerland (where it is restricted to a small area in Kanton Ticino), east to the Trieste and Istria regions of north-eastern Italy, with a few subpopulations in Slovenia and Croatia (Grossenbacher 1982, 1997a,b; Barbieri and Mazzotti 2006). Sites have been found in western Slovenia in the valleys of rivers Vipava, Branica, Idrija, and Goriškabrda, and more recently in Istria (Poboljšaj et al. 2007, Lešnik et al. 2011, Stanković and Poboljšaj 2013). In Croatia, it is present in the central and northern part of Istria (Kuljerić 2011, Jelić et al. 2012). It is present from sea level up to around 500 m asl, but sites at higher elevations than 300 m asl are unusual (Grossenbacher 1997, Barbieri and Mazzotti 2006). An isolated subpopulation near Ravenna, coastal Italy, it considered to be possibly extinct.

Its area of occupancy (AOO) is 1,450 km2, which consists of 856 km2 in Italy, 40 km2 in Switzerland, 136 km2 in Croatia and 400 km2 in Slovenia (K. Poboljšaj pers. comm. June 2020).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)

This European endemic species is listed as Vulnerable because its area of occupancy (AOO) is 1,450 km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat, and a decline in the number of mature individuals due to the effects of invasive crayfish. With only a small portion of the range outside of the EU27 Member States (Switzerland), the species is also assessed as Vulnerable for the EU27 region.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is threatened by the destruction of much of the original humid deciduous forests of the Padano Venetian plain and Istrian region by extensive agricultural development including drainage and deforestation (with population fragmentation).

Additional threats to this species are the introduction of predatory fishes and crayfish, lowering of the water table, and aquatic pollution. Invasions of crayfish are known to have a negative impact on amphibian communities (Ficetola et al. 2012a) and can affect population dynamics even in non-invaded patches, through the degradation of subpopulation networks (Manenti et al. 2019). Crayfish are present in the Italian, Swiss and likely the Croatian parts of this species' range, and the invasion of crayfish is expected in the near future in Slovenia which will also threaten subpopulations there (Stanković et al. 2015; K. Poboljšaj pers. comm. July 2020). They may have caused the extinction of this species from part of its range (Ficetola et al. 2012b).

The reduced genetic diversity in western subpopulations might be leading to greater vulnerability to emergent pathogens (Garner and Pearman 2001, Garner and Tomio 2001, Garner et al. 2003; T. Garner pers. comm.).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is probably present in several Natural Parks in Galicia and Asturias, and in Picos de Europa National Park in Asturias.

Conservation Needed
Conservation measures should focus on habitat protection, especially breeding sites, which are often small and temporary and thus neglected.

Research Needed
The contact zone with Rana temporaria needs to be further delimited in northwest Spain.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species occurs in largely the same types of habitat as Rana temporaria including heathland, peat bogs, forests, and grasslands. It is very sensitive to habitat disturbance and loss (Galán 1999). Its breeds in a wide variety of temporary ponds (Galán 1982, 1999) by larval development.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is relatively common in most of Galicia, except in the southeast of the region (Galán 1999, Galán and Cabana 2008). It is locally abundant in Asturias (Álvarez 2014). Galán (1999) reported subpopulation declines associated with habitat loss, and due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitats, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Europe, where it occurs in northwest Spain, in the regions of Galicia and Asturias and the provinces of Zamora, León and Palencia (Dufresnes et al. 2020, AHE 2021). In Galicia, it occurs between sea level to 1,900 m asl (Galán 1999) and in Asturias it occurs up to 2,200 m asl (Álvarez 2014). It is not likely to occur more widely (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).
RedListRationale.value: The Galician Common Frog (Rana parvipalmata) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to northwestern Spain. It is assessed Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Large-scale habitat loss associated with changes in land use (development, fire, logging), especially at low altitudes is a major threat (Álvarez 2014). In high-altitude subpopulations, the introduction of alien fish species (different species of salmonids) for sport fishing has a negative impact on this species (Orizaola and Braña 2006). Massive mortality due to road kills has also been reported in some areas (Diego-Rasilla and Ortiz-Santaliestra 2009).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is used as a food source, but not frequently and it is presumed that the impact is minimal (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in Ordesa and Monte Perdido National Park (Huesca) and Lizardoia Integral Reserve (Navarra). It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is included in the Spanish and the regional catalogues of Navarra and Aragón and in the Red Book of France (UICN France et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, and the control of invasive species.

Research Needed
Population and disease monitoring are required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species lives in and close to rocky mountain streams and torrents in which the water is cold, clear and well oxygenated, and is also found in roadside and forest edge ditches, drinking troughs and rain pools. Breeding takes place in these waterbodies.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
Subpopulations are common in the headwaters of valleys in Huesca Province, while in Navarra subpopulations are scattered in the west. It is not a common species and is hard to find due to its secretive nature, and it is considered to be very rare in France and very localised (P.-A. Crochet pers. comm. October 2022). The global population is fragmented into three groups in south-western and south-eastern Pyrenees and the northern Pyrenees; these subpopulation groups are genetically differentiated and host low levels of genetic diversity (Carranza and Arribas 2008, Gosá et al. 2010).

At least within the last ten years, declines have been observed in subpopulations in the western part of the Pyrenees due to invasive crayfish (R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Based on tadpole density and breeding sites, this decline is thought to have been about 30% of the subpopulation there (R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is largely restricted to the southern slopes of the western central Pyrenees Mountains. In Spain, it occurs from the Aezkoa Valley (Irati, Navarra) eastwards to Parque Nacional de Ordesa in Huesca (Gosá and Rubio 2018). In France, it occurs in the Iraty Forest in the western French Pyrenees (Pyrénées-Atlantiques department), and has been reported from the northern slope of the Pyrenees in the Aspe and Cize valleys (also in the Pyrénées-Atlantiques department; Duchateau et al. 2012). It occurs between 440-2,100 m asl. Its EOO is 4,915 km2, and the AOO, whilst uncertain as based on GBIF data, is c.396 km2.
RedListRationale.value: The Pyrenean Frog (Rana pyrenaica) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to the Pyrenees Mountains. It is assessed as Endangered (B1ab(iii,iv,v)+2ab(iii,iv,v)) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,915 km2, the area of occupancy (AOO), whilst uncertain, is less than 500 km2, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and in the number of mature individuals. Monitoring is required to understand the impact of threats, including novel diseases.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Threats include habitat loss caused by small-scale agriculture and logging (R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019), stream eutrophication (through intensification of agricultural practices), drought, potential introduction of trout and other predatory fishes, and habitat loss due to the development of tourism and transport infrastructure. In the western side of its range, the introduction of crayfish has caused the species to decline (R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019).

Some samples had tested positive for chytridiomycosis (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, Bd) but this had not been associated with mortalities (Gosá et al. 2010). However, Peso Fernández (2018) found Bd across the range of the Pyrenean Frog, with higher frequency of infection found in low- to mid-elevation elevations, and noted that higher elevation populations could be exposed to the pathogen in the future under climate change scenarios. The impact of Bd on this species is not known, but presence of the disease may be one factor explaining the low population sizes of this species (Peso Fernández 2018). The species is very sensitive to infection by Ranavirus (Bosch et al. 2020). Species distribution modelling projects a 100% loss of the potential range of the species in the period 2041-2070 (Araújo et al. 2011).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is protected by national legislation in most range countries (e.g. Switzerland, Slovenia) and it is present in a number of protected areas, including in Natura 2000 sites (e.g., Monti Lessini - Pasubio - Piccole Dolomiti Vicentine (IT3210040) and Altopiano dei Sette Comuni IT3220036). It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and Salamandra atra aurorae is listed on Annex II of the EU Natural Habitats Directive under the name 'Salamandra salamandra aurorae'; both this species and 'Salamandra aurorae' are also listed on Annex IV of the Directive. The subspecies S. a. aurorae is present in the Natura 2000 site of Cima Dodici (10,450 ha) while S. a. pasubiensis occurs in the Natura 2000 site Pasubio e Piccole Dolomiti (1,920 ha).

Gasc et al. (1997) considered Salamandra atra aurorae to be highly endangered.

Conservation Needed
Kalezic and Dzukic (2001) suggest the establishment of a protected area on Prokletije Mount would significantly aid the conservation of this species in the Dinaric Alps. There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union)-wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is found in cool, damp alpine meadows, stony pastures, dwarf heath and mixed, broadleaf and coniferous woodland. Animals are usually hidden below stones and logs, but can be encountered in shady places, or after rain, during the day. The species is unusual in that it has a ovi-viviparous method of reproduction by which it gives birth on land to an average of two fully metamorphosed offspring; the gestation period is between two and four years. It may be found in pastureland and other slightly modified habitats. It is not associated with water.

S.a. aurorae is strictly associated with mature forest habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is still abundant in Switzerland (although now considered to be extinct in some southern parts of the country), Germany, Austria and parts of Italy. In Italy the nominal subspecies it is found in good numbers and is considered to be stable (Romano et al. 2018, Romano et al. 2021). It appears to be more rare and threatened in the Dinaric Alps in Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Serbia-Montenegro and northern Albania (e.g. Kalezic and Dzukic 2001). Due to ongoing local decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to Europe, where it is present in the European Alps (including a recently discovered subpopulation close to the village of Samoëns in the Département de la Haute-Savoie, France), with isolated subpopulations in the Balkan Dinaric Alps in Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro and northern Albania. It occurs at elevations between 400 and 2,800 m asl (more frequent between 800–2,000 m asl).

Although their taxonomic status requires confirmation, the subspecies Salamandra atra aurorae is restricted to the “sette Comuni” plateau and east almost up to the Piana di Marcesina in northeast Italy (between 1,300 and 1,800 m asl), on the Venetian Prealps and in a small portion of the Trento province. The subspecies S. a. pasubiensis occurs only on the southern slope of Monte Pasubio (Veneto region), with some other reports on the same mountain massif lacking confirmation.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
There are generally no threats to the Italian subpopulations of Salamandra atra atra. Some local subpopulations in Switzerland are threatened by road mortality and subpopulations of the Dinaric Alps are threatened by localised habitat destruction through intensification of farming methods, tourism (skiing) and infrastructure development. The subspecies S. a. aurorae is threatened by collection for scientific purposes and the pet trade and general habitat alteration, and the removal of ground cover during forestry practices; the storm VAIA in 2018 severely altered the forest habitat of this salamander and studies are currently underway to evaluate the impact. Subpopulations in Serbia and Montenegro are small, fragmented and threatened by over-collecting for the pet trade and possibly climatic changes.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Mortality in captivity has been observed due to the Bsal (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). Along with declines observed in congener S. salamandra, it can be considered to be a threat to this species.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is collected for the national and international pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in a number of protected areas, and in parts of its range mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and is included in Annex II of the Habitats Directive of the European Union (Council Directive 92/43/EEC), i.e. species of community interest whose conservation requires the designation of special areas of conservation. It is considered Vulnerable in Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is found in open habitats with mixed deciduous forests and groves, bushlands, flooded meadows and swamps, and also in agricultural landscapes (irrigation channels) and villages, and riparian groves in the steppe regions. It might in some instances be strictly aquatic. This species may coexist with fish in oxbow lakes, river margins and other non-temporary waterbodies, and may also occur in disturbed habitats including those close to human settlement (Griffiths 1996).

Reproduction takes place in small ponds with stagnant water, or in channels, irrigation channels, ditches and flooded quarries. Facultative paedomorphosis was reported from Hungary (Mester et al. 2013). It appears to be a short-lived species, with the oldest individuals in the wild being 4–6 years old (Cogălniceanu and Miaud 2002, 2003).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
In general, subpopulations of this species are rapidly declining as a result of habitat loss from associated wetlands in the floodplains of the Danube River and its main tributaries (D. Cogălniceanu pers. comm. August 2020). Over the last 10 years, a rough estimate of population decline is 10–20% (D. Cogălniceanu pers. comm. August 2021).

Two subspecies were originally proposed, a western and an eastern one (Litvinchuk and Borkin 2000), but this hypothesis was generally not supported (Wielstra et al. 2016) and the species is considered as monotypic.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This European endemic species is found in the lowlands of the Tisza and Danube River systems from eastern Austria, extreme southeastern Czechia, Slovakia, Hungary, northern Croatia, extreme northern Bosnia-Herzegovina, northern Serbia and western Romania, southern and southeastern Romania including the Danube Delta and its lagoon system, northern Bulgaria, southern Moldova (the lower reaches of the Prut River), and extreme southern Odesskaya Province (Ukraine) (Vörös et al. 2016). It is present also in Slovenia in the River Mura floodplain.

An isolated subpopulation was reported from the Dnieper River Delta, Kherson Province, Ukraine by Litvinchuk (2005). Records added since the 2008 assessment include northeastern Bulgaria (Ghergel and Iftime 2009). It is generally found in lowland areas, mostly floodplains, below 300 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The main threats to this species are rapid anthropogenic habitat destruction (for example, through drainage and damming), and pollution of its wetland habitats (especially floodplains). In the southern part of its range, there has been loss of breeding habitats in recent years due to increased aridisation (Ionita et al. 2016), perhaps as a result of global climate change. In the south of Romania the collapse of the former widespread irrigation system has caused a decrease in the level of underground water, and water pollution and alien species (plants and fish) are also thought to be considered as threats (D. Cogălniceanu pers. comm. August 2021). Urbanisation is also causing local declines in some areas e.g. north of Budapest (D. Cogălniceanu pers. comm. August 2021). A gradual decrease in the number was noted in the delta of the Dnieper River in Ukraine (Litvinchuk and Borkin 2002). This species has an extremely low abundance in Moldova (Litvinchuk and Borkin 1995).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013) Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017).

Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species will not be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years. However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within or nearer to this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.

Ranavirus was detected on the species in Hungary (Vörös et al. 2020).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is present in many protected areas across its range. It is not presently listed as a separate species on Appendix II of the Bern Convention nor on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, but included under the previous range of Triturus carnifex. Is it protected by national legislation, but under the name of Triturus carnifex, in Serbia, Montenegro and Albania. It is recorded as Least Concern in the national Red Data books and lists in Albania (under the name Triturus carnifex - Anonymous 2013), Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015) and Greece (Legakis and Maragou 2009).

Conservation Needed
Certain conservation actions should focus on the few reported subpopulations that exhibit facultative paedomorphosis; five in Montenegro (Kalezić et al. 1994, Denoël et al. 2009, Slijepcevic 2015), one in Albania (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. obs.) and one in Greece (Sotiropoulos et al. 2017c). There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission. Long term monitoring of this species is required.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its population and ecology, and monitoring of habitat trends is recommended. If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The species occurs in a wide variety of terrestrial habitats, from beech woodlands to arid Mediterranean climates. It can be found in ponds and lakes as well as in modified habitats such as quarries and artificial water bodies such as stony wells, tanks (water reservoirs) and drinking troughs (Denoël 2004). However, not all water bodies within an area are suitable for this species: only three of nine small water bodies regularly monitored since 2017 at Vlasina plateau in Southeastern Serbia harbour this species (Crnobrnja-Isailović, unpublished data). Adults are presumed to be relatively more aquatic than Triturus ivanbureschi (Wielstra and Arntzen 2011). Its breeding and larval development takes place in various stagnant, preferably permanent or long standing, temporary aquatic habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Some subpopulations are still large, but they are generally declining throughout the range. More than half (>50%) of the individuals (or more than half of the occupied habitat area) are in small and isolated patches between which there is little to no dispersal. The population is therefore considered to be likely severely fragmented.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to the European region (Sillero et al. 2014), where it is distributed across south-eastern Europe from eastern Bosnia and Herzegovina (Adrović 2015); western, south-western, southern and most of south-eastern parts of Serbia (Kalezić et al. 2015); through all of Montenegro (Ćirović 2015) and Albania (Haxhiu 2015) where this species was wrongly synonymised with T. cristatus (see also Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2018); the majority of North Macedonia (Sterijovski and Arsovski 2020); western parts of Greece (Legakis and Maragou 2009); and western Bulgaria (Naumov and Tzankov 2008). It has been recorded from sea level to elevations approaching 2,140 m asl in Greece (Denoël 2004). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 197,586 km2. The EOO for the EU27 has not been estimated but is likely to exceed 20,000 km2.

Presently, 240 breeding sites have been recorded: 139 recorded in Wielstra and Arntzen (2012); an additional 12 in Vučič et al. (2020); 25 in Sotiropoulos et al. 2013, 2017b, 2017c)); nine in Ioannidis et al. (2014); 15 in Denoël et al. (2009); 15 in Denoël (2004) and 25 localities in Szabolcs et al. (2017). The dispersal ability of this species depends on the existence of suitable corridors e.g. connectivity of individual aquatic habitats (Sotiropoulos et al. 2013). However, this does not characterise the majority of its breeding sites. Using these breeding sites to estimate the species' area of occupancy (AOO) should therefore result in a fairly accurate estimate. As such, if each breeding site is contained within a 4 km2 grid cell, the maximum AOO is 960 km2. For the EU27 region, the AOO is estimated at 212 km2 (based on: Greece, 52 localities, AOO 208 km2; one locality in western Bulgaria, AOO 4 km2) (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. 2022).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Endangered (EN)

This European endemic species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU B2ab(iii,v)) globally because its area of occupancy (AOO) is 960 km2, which is based on the area of breeding sites and likely to be an overestimate, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and number of mature individuals particularly in relation to breeding sites.

In the EU 27 Member States the species occurs in Greece and western Bulgaria (where it is currently known from a single locality), with a restricted AOO of 212 km2. The population is considered to be severely fragmented and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the number of mature individuals, particularly in relation to breeding sites. As a result, the species is assessed as Endangered (B2ab(iii,v)), with no rescue effect applied.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The principal threat to the species is the loss of aquatic habitats, especially breeding sites, through agricultural intensification as well as habitat deterioration by agrochemical pollution, and the introduction of fish.

In the range countries in economic transition (Albania - Haxhiu 2015, Montenegro - Ćirović 2015, Bosnia and Herzegovina-Adrović 2015, Serbia - Crnobrnja-Isailović and Paunović 2015, North Macedonia – Sterijovski 2015), ongoing and increasing demographic changes in human population and habitat alteration represent a threat (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2005, Ćirović et al. 2008, Sotiropoulos et al. 2013, Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2018), even in protected areas (Bego et al. 2012).

Aquatic habitats suitable for breeding for this species are under the high pressure in the western Balkan countries (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022). In the central parts of the species' distribution range, there has been permanent or temporary loss of some breeding habitats in recent years (recorded from 2003, Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2005) due to decreased spring rains, perhaps as result of climate change.

Predicted habitat suitability on the basis of recent climate layers is fairly to moderately positive for approximately 60% of the species area (Wielstra et al. 2013). However, it was projected that only 39% of occupied sites will be suitable by 2080 (Pearman et al. 2010 using data from Arntzen et al. 2007). Additionally, most subpopulations are genetically quite uniform throughout the range (Wielstra et al. 2013, Fig 4).

Sporadic infection wit Bd was reported from the Montenegrin part of the Lake Skadar region (Vojar et al. 2017).

June 2021). On a precautionary basis, it is thought that it is unlikely that wild subpopulations would have much resistance to Bsal and it is considered to be a possible threat to this species. ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in Parque Nacional de Cabañeros and Parque Nacional de Doñana, Spain, and is presumed to occur in some Portuguese protected areas. In protected areas of Andalucia (Parque Nacional Los Alcornocales) and unprotected natural areas (Sierra de Córdoba), active conservation programmes have been carried out for this species, recovering the connection between natural subpopulations (R. Reques and I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019). This species is listed in Annex III of the Bern Convention and is protected by national and sub-national legislation in Spain.

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Bsal monitoring should continue and if it is detected within this species' range, then it should be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species inhabits broadleaf (Quercus oak) woodland in meso-Mediterranean and thermo-Mediterranean climates. Aquatic habitats used for breeding and larval development include temporary or permanent ponds, abandoned quarries and wells, drinking troughs, irrigation ponds, ditches and other areas of stagnant or slow-moving water with aquatic vegetation. It is found in traditional farmland areas and other slightly modified habitats. Egg laying behaviour of females includes the protection of each egg by wrapping them into folded leaves of aquatic plants. Therefore, the presence of aquatic submerged vegetation in breeding ponds is essential for successful reproduction.

Its generation length is estimated to be around three years, which is based on the various reproductive and longevity data that exist for both the Spanish and Portuguese subpopulations of this species (e.g. Diaz-Paniagua 1986, Caetano 1990, Caetano and Castanet 1993, Díaz-Paniagua et al. 1996).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is common in areas where suitable siliceous substrate habitat exists. There has been a significant and severe decline in the populations of southern and eastern Spain (those found on a calcareous substrate). It is estimated that around 30% of the subpopulation in Spain has decreased in the last 10–20 years, which may be a conservative estimate of around 20% of the known global population as two-thirds of the entire distributional range occurs within the country (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. July 2021). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and predation from various species, the population is inferred to continue to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European species is endemic to the Iberian Peninsula where it is distributed in central and southern Portugal and the southern half of Spain, from sea level to 1,450 m asl.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Near Threatened because it is in decline, estimated to be 20% over the last ten years over its entire range because of widespread habitat loss and predation by various invasive species, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion A2.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The most significant threat to this species overall is habitat loss, especially the loss of temporary ponds. In the west of Spain and southern Portugal populations are affected by predation and competition by non-native crayfish and fish. Increasing urbanisation surrounding Madrid has also led to the elimination of many subpopulations. This is extensible to several areas of Andalusia (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019). In southern and eastern Spain, over-exploitation of groundwater resources, agrochemical pollution, loss of traditional breeding sites and the introduction of predatory non-native fish and crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) has led to a serious population decline. In Portugal this species is also affected by the drainage of temporary ponds, associated with the intensification of agriculture. In southern and western Spain, the alteration and destruction of the reproductive areas of this newt have been very pronounced in recent decades (R. Reques and I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019). Early pond desiccation over consecutive breeding seasons has been observed to cause high larval mortality and repeated failure to recruit juveniles (R. Reques and I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. November 2019).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that this species is susceptible to infection, with 100% mortality observed in captivity (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). There are no current records of Bsal within this species range, although it is present in Spain, however, it should be monitored if an outbreak occurs. Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species will not be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years. However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within or nearer to this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several regional and national parks in Aragón including Ordesa and Monte Perdido National Parks, and in Catalonia including Aigüestortes and Estany de Sant Maurici National Parks.

Conservation Needed
Habitat protection and improving connectivity between isolated subpopulations are important conservation measures (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021).

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, as it is important to clarify range boundaries of this species with Alytes obstetricans (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021). Due to the sensitivity of species in the genus to diseases like chytridiomycosis it is also important to monitor the health status of populations of the species (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is a habitat generalist and can be found in a broad variety of terrestrial habitats, including high-altitude meadows, forests at different elevations (Fagus, Pinus, Quercus, mixed forests), agricultural areas, and even urban gardens and parks, as long as there are suitable breeding habitats [water tanks, artificial ponds] (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. April 2021).

Similar to other species in the genus; mating takes place on land, males carry eggs for several weeks before releasing free-swimming larvae in aquatic habitats (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021). It requires permanent or semi-permanent water bodies for breeding, but can tolerate a degree of habitat disturbance as they can use artificial water bodies for breeding (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is relatively common throughout its range (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the effects of various diseases, invasive species and road mortalities, the population is inferred to be decreasing. Effects of predatory invasive species has been linked to local extinctions, but this is thought to be affecting <10% of its range (Í. Martínez-Solano and A. Montori pers. comm. April 2021).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species occurs in southeastern France and northeastern Spain from Aragon and Catalonia (Dufresnes and Martínez-Solano 2020), between 0–2,300 m asl (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021). Its range is not fully understood in southeastern France and further research is required (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The major threats to this species include habitat destruction and degradation due to urbanisation and the use of herbicides and pesticides in rural areas, the introduction of alien invasive species (different species of turtles especially Trachemys, crayfish - mostly Procambarus clarkii, and several fish which prey on Alytes larvae and their presence has been linked to local extinctions), emerging infectious diseases (chytridiomycosis, ranavirus), and road mortality (Í. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. January 2021).

Conservation Actions In-Place:
The species is presumed to occur in a number of protected areas. It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and is protected by national legislation in many of its range states.

Research Needed:
Further research into the current decline is needed especially into the impacts of disease.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species lives in terrestrial habitats, including temperate forests, semi-arid areas, walls, embankments, and slopes with small stones and sparse vegetation. It can occur in suitable modified habitat such as traditional agricultural land, and even urban areas (e.g. in Barcelona). Aquatic habitats in which the species breeds range from slow moving rivers to stagnant permanent ponds and pools; gravel and clay pits are also used. The larvae of this species frequently hibernate.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is reported to be declining (including local extinctions) across its range, but it is still widespread and common in many areas (e.g. in much of France). There have been local extinctions within Spain caused by chytridiomycosis (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. September 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species ranges from the northern half of Portugal and Spain (where subpopulations are very fragmented, and there is a small area of occupancy within its extent of occurrence), through most of France, to southern Belgium, extreme southeastern Netherlands, Luxembourg, western and north-central Germany, and western and northern Switzerland. Subpopulations in coastal Portugal west of Lisbon are extinct. It has been introduced to the U.K., with at least one established subpopulation (not mapped). It occurs at elevations ranging from sea level up to 2,400 m asl (in the Pyrenees). Maiorano et al. (2013) estimated the species' extent of occurrence (EOO) as 1,056,482 km².

Following genetic analysis, subpopulations from N. Aragón and most of Catalonia, Spain have now been assigned to Alytes almogavarii (Dufresnes and Martinez-Solano 2020).

The species is also assessed as Least Concern for the EU 27 member states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: General habitat loss, largely due to agricultural development (including loss of breeding sites), has contributed to the decline of the species in some areas. Fragmentation of subpopulations might be a problem for the species in Spain and Portugal. Certain subpopulations of the subspecies Alytes obstetricans pertinax in protected areas of central Spain have severely declined and disappeared as a result of chytridiomycosis (Bosch et al. 2000, 2001); a few specimens have recently been found again in this area (M. García-París and J.W. Arntzen pers. comm.). Additional mortality of the species through disease (iridovirus) has been recorded in Carris Lake, Peneda-Gerês National Park, Portugal (Soares et al. 2003); the disease might be non-native and have been transferred to the lake by an introduced predatory fish (Lepomis gibbosus). Predation by L. gibbosus and other introduced predatory fish species, such as salmonids, is also a considerable threat to this species.
