ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation over much of its range and is present in many protected areas. There were several EC-funded LIFE-projects targeting the species or its habitats: https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/life/publicWebsite/search/get?basicSearchText=bombina+variegata.

Conservation Needed
Re-introductions of the species might be needed in parts of the range.

Research Needed
There is a need to monitor population changes in this species, especially in the hybrid zone between B. variegata and B. bombina. The impact of collection for trade and scientific purposes also needs to be researched. Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis& related population declines should be investigated, especially focusing on tadpoles or early development phase, as detectability of mortality at this age is very difficult (Harmos et al. 2021).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species can be found in coniferous, deciduous and mixed forests, bushlands and meadows, floodplains and grasslands, pastures and Mediterranean maquis. At low elevations this species lives in deciduous forests, at higher altitudes it is more often found in coniferous forests and highland glades. The species uses many types of wetland, including lakes, ponds, swamps, rivers, stream pools, springs (including mineral and thermal springs), puddles, reservoirs, gravel pits, drinking trough, concrete tanks, ditches and even water filled wheel ruts. The breeding habitats are typically unshaded temporary pools within, or close to, woodland. The species can tolerate slight water pollution, and has been recorded at very high densities in areas of cleared woodland in the Carpathian Mountains. It breeds by larval development.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
The species has experienced some local extinctions and subpopulation declines (e.g., southern Switzerland, northwestern and southern France). Populations of the Italian endemic subspecies, Bombina variegata pachypus, suffered a dramatic decline: in the last decades populations has declined in almost all its range (with the exception of Calabria, where the population remains stable). From a survey of representative sites it emerged that between 1996 and 2004 the species disappeared from more than 50% of the sites examined (56 sites occupied in 1996 against 23 occupied in 2004: Barbieri et al. 2004). Significant declines were recorded (both in presence site and in population abundance) in the whole Italian peninsula in the last 10 years (Romano, Coppari, Ficetola, Manenti, pers. comm.) In Slovenia, the species is widespread, but numbers are decreasing with no apparent habitat loss (K. Poboljšaj pers. comm. September 2019). In Czechia, subpopulations are fragmented and some have disappeared for unknown reasons (A. Krása pers. comm. September 2019).

In Türkiye, declines in abundance of this species in Kurtkaya and Sögütlüdere have been observed, with declines thought to be caused by pinworm drug mixtures being added to water sources to protect cattle from pinworm cyst infection by farmers, while individuals in the Hisarli subpopulation are highly affected by declining water supplies (Bulbul et al. 2018). It is suspected to be decreasing in Bulgaria (Y. Kornilev, G. Popgeorgiev and B. Naumov pers. comm. October 2019). However, over parts of its range such as the Carpathian Mountains, Poland and Albania, it is still common in suitable habitat.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is distributed over much of central and Southern Europe. It is generally present from central France through southern Germany and northern and western Switzerland, much of Italy, the Balkan region and the Carpathian Mountains. Isolated subpopulations are present in northwestern Italy, and Hungary (Vörös et al. 2006), and its range in northwestern France is now severely fragmented. Its range has been expanded in Türkiye, where it is found in Karacahasan Mountains (Edirne) near the Greek border (Bülbül et al. 2018), and it has been reported from Moldovian Romania (Pop et al. 2019).

It is probably extinct in Belgium (former range not mapped), and some subpopulations have been lost in the south of France. The presence of isolated subpopulations in southwestern France (Medoc and Landes) requires confirmation, and they have been mapped as 'Presence Uncertain' until their identity is determined.

It has been introduced to the United Kingdom, but it is not known if the species is still present and is not mapped here. Maiorano et al. (2013) estimated the species' extent of occurrence (EOO) as 1,211,800.76 km². It occurs between 100–2,100 m asl.

The species is also considered Least Concern for the EU27 member states.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Subpopulations of this species might be locally threatened by the loss of suitable habitat due to urbanization, road construction, industry (including oil extraction and transportation) and discharge of pollutants into wetlands. Pesticides may also be a problem (A. Krása pers. comm. September 2019). Additionally, it is reported that it is collected as bait by fishermen in certain regions and that it is occasionally collected in large numbers for both the pet trade and scientific use. The impact of collection on this species needs further research. In Bulgaria, an additional threat is the development of mini-hydroelectric power stations (Y. Kornilev, G. Popgeorgiev and B. Naumov pers. comm. October 2019) as well as in entire Balkan Peninsula (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021).

In Türkiye, in addition to urban and agricultural development, it is threatened by declining water supplies, water pollution from contamination from drug mixtures to protect the cattle from pinworm cyst infection and the collection of specimens for scientific purposes (Bülbül et al. 2018). At a global scale, the species appears not to be significantly threatened while at regional level, as in the case of the Italian endemic B. v. pachypus, may be exposed to severe extinction risk. Climatic changes in Europe, with long arid periods in active season, affect the species at a large scale negatively, due to lack of available water bodies in breeding season, delaying or cancelling breeding of certain populations.

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has been recorded in this species, but no negative effects or mass mortalities have been observed to date (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). In 2021, it was detected to cause mortalities in Hungary (Harmos et al. 2021). Although studies conducted in the Netherlands show that the nominal subspecies appears relatively resistant to the fungal pathogen Bd (Spitzen-van der Sluijs et al. 2017), this is nevertheless considered partially responsible for the large decline of the Italian endemic subspecies B. v. pachypus (Barbieri et al. 2004, Canestrelli et al. 2013).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is found in the pet trade and is used for scientific purposes, although the impact of its collection needs to be investigated. It is also used as bait by fisherman.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: This species occurs in protected areas. There have been some reintroductions in Ibiza, and some habitat restoration (restoration of water tanks) has been carried out. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and Annex IV of the Habitats Directive (as Bufo viridis).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is generally a lowland species, where it occupies coastal areas (typically but not exclusively sand dunes), cultivated areas, and suburban and urban areas where it is found in gravel and sand pits, ponds and ditches. It is also found in water tanks in the Balearic Islands. It breeds by direct development.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is common with stable subpopulations in suitable habitats in Italy. Within the Balearic Islands, where possible introduced, it is common except for on Ibiza. It is declining slowly on Majorca and more rapidly on Ibiza as a result of loss of breeding habitat.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species ranges through much of Italy, including the island of Sardinia, some major circum-Sardinian islands (Corti et al. 2006), the easternmost parts of Sicily, and Corsica (France). It occurs in the Balearic Islands of Spain, probably introduced in prehistoric times. It is found from sea level up to 1,330 m asl in central Italy (Romano et al. 2003, Spilinga 2007).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: In the Balearic Islands, where the origin of the species is uncertain, loss and degradation of breeding habitat has resulted from excessive water abstraction, urbanization, decline of traditional agricultural practices and pollution with agrochemicals. Fragmentation as a result of road construction is also a problem. Urbanisation decreases regular annual breeding through fragmentation and degradation of suitable green areas (Guarino et al. 2021).

This species is endemic to Cyprus. However, the majority of records are known from the north and west of the island, with the type locality (“near Finikaria”) in the south. The species has not been recorded in higher elevations of Troodos Mountains (Kyriakopoulou-Sklavounou et al. 2003, Stöck et al. 2006, Baier et al. 2009, Göçmen et al. 2008, Dufresnes et al. 2019).

It is assessed as Near Threatened (B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii)) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is less than 14,427 km2, the area of occupancy (AOO) is less than 500 km2 based on available locality data, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. It is tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance hence it is unlikely that current threats are significant enough to be causing a severe reduction within a short period of time, or that it is severely fragmented. However as threats are expected to intensify it is likely to qualify for either severe fragmentation or less than ten locations in the not too distant future.

Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and is also listed on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in both Portugal and Spain. It occurs in several protected areas including Picos de Europa National Park and Fragas do Eume Natural Park, Spain, and Peneda-Gerês National Park, Portugal. Local conservation initiatives such as replanting native tree species and thus recovering terrestrial habitats for this and other wild species are examples of good practice involving non-governmental as well as governmental organisations and other actors in collective, neo-endogenous action (Swagemakers and Dominguez-Garcia 2015).

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be implemented immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The species is associated with clear, well-oxygenated, small- to medium-sized slightly acidic streams (although in Portugal it has been found in water with pH 7–8), with dense surrounding vegetation in mountainous and hilly areas. The species has also been recorded from caves and abandoned flooded mines. It is associated with broad-leaved oak forest, and occurs in secondary vegetation, but not in commercial plantations. It is a larval developer, and the females lay approximately 12–20 eggs in shallow stream water, often attaching the eggs to the bottom substrate. It is sometimes associated with areas of traditional farming practices, and is particularly found in dry stonewalls.

The generation length is estimated to be 5–6 years, which is based on skeletochronology studies by Texeira et al. (1998) and Lima et al. (2001) (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This is a localised species that can be abundant in suitable habitats (4–5 adults per metre of brook habitat). The 2008 assessment reported that eastern Spanish subpopulations are found at lower population densities, and there have been reports of declines and extinctions of some subpopulations in Galicia (Galán 1999, 2009). It was also reported that some subpopulations in northwestern Spain have disappeared following the replacement of broad-leaved forests with other habitats. Despite increased sampling efforts, data from the Spanish Herpetological Society shows a high proportion of 10x10 km grids where the species has not been recorded post-2000 (using the Corte por año option on the species page: AHE 2021). It is estimated that a population decline suspected to be between 20–30% has occurred within the Spanish subpopulations over the last 15–18 years (which represents three generation lengths for this species). In Portugal, subpopulations are widespread and abundant (P. Arntzen pers. comm.) and not in any immediate danger, but they are considered to be vulnerable because of their specialised habitat requirements (Paulo 1997). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing. Population modelling by Arntzen (2015) showed a sharp decline in population size and increased larval mortality in a population occurring in a gum tree plantation.

This species is comprised of two subspecies (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species is restricted to mountainous and hilly areas in north-western Spain (Galicia and Asturias) and northern and central Portugal with an annual precipitation of over 1,000 mm. Its distribution is patchy because its required habitat is fragmented. It has been introduced to the Serra de Sintra, west of Lisbon. It occurs between 100–1,396 m asl (although there are few records above 1,000 m asl - e.g. Sequeira and Alexandrino 2008, Otero and Galán 2017). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 55,468 km<sup>2</sup>.

Climate change could be a serious threat for this species in the following decades due to shifts in available suitable habitat, according to climatic modelling (Cruz et al. 2016).

Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within or nearer to this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.

Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed in many regional, national and sub-national Red Data Books and Lists, and is present in many protected areas. It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and is protected by national and sub-national legislation throughout much of its range. A re-introduction programme in the UK has successfully established at least six, and perhaps quite a few more subpopulations (Denton et al. 1997, Zippel 2005). However, it is considered Endangered EN B2ab(iii) for amphibian RL of Great Britain. In Czechia, it is listed as Critically Endangered and there are plans to develop a national action plan for it (A. Krása pers. comm. September 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection and management is required for this species.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally found in open and unshaded light sandy soils of coastal dunes, lowland heaths, semi-deserts, high mountains, pine forest glades, gardens, parks, agricultural fields, sand and gravel quarries and meadows. In the daytime, these animals hide in heaps of stones, in sandy soil and under debris. Spawning, followed by a short larval development period, takes place in sunny shallow temporary pools and lagoons. This is a pioneering species in much of Southern Europe, sometimes temporarily colonising new ponds; it is very much less adaptable in northern Europe.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is locally abundant across much of its range, especially in southern Europe. It is much more localised and is declining in the northern parts of its range (e.g. in the United Kingdom [including loss of breeding sites - J. Wilkinson pers. comm. September 2019], Ireland, Belgium, Denmark, Sweden and Estonia). While generally declining in Poland, a large breeding subpopulation of about 500 individuals was recorded in 2002 in the Slowinski National Park. In Czechia, it is declining on the edge of its distribution and has been since the middle of the 20th century due to habitat loss and degradation (A. Krása pers. comm. September 2019). Over the last 25 years, the subpopulation in the Netherlands has also been declining (R. Zollinger pers. comm. September 2019). In Kaliningrad Province (European Russia) the subpopulation was relatively common in some regions until 2012, but completely extinct in 2020 due to succession and the lack of suitable reservoirs for reproduction (S.N. Litvinchuk and G.V. Grishanov pers. comm. October 2022).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is found in southern, western and northern Europe, ranging from Portugal and Spain, north to Denmark, southern Sweden, and as far east as western Ukraine, Belarus, Latvia and Estonia. There are isolated subpopulations in southwestern Ireland and scattered parts of the United Kingdom (north to southwestern Scotland). It occurs from sea level up to almost 2,540 m asl (in Spain).

The Natterjack Toad (Epidalea calamita) is European endemic species. Although there have been declines across parts of the European region, it is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 Member States in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The main threats to this species are the loss of specialised habitats (such as heaths and dunes) by natural encroachment of scrub and woodland; afforestation, acidification of breeding pools, agricultural development, infilling of breeding sites (such as temporary pools and sand and gravel quarries); increased mechanisation of sand and gravel extraction and infrastructure development for tourism. Climate change is also a threat to this species (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Road mortality can produce high mortality during spring migrations in Iberian populations (Gómez Mestre 2014) and probably elsewhere.

Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. The species is protected by national legislation in many countries, it is recorded in many national and sub-national Red Data books and lists and it is present in many protected areas. It is considered Endangered in Switzerland (Schmidt and Zumbach 2005), Vulnerable in Austria (Gollmann 2007) and Slovenia (Anonymous 2010), Near Threatened in France (UICN France et al. 2015), Czechia (Chobot and Nemec 2017) and Romania (Botnariuc and Tatole 2005). The species is Least Concern in Sweden (SLU Artdatabanken 2020).

In parts of this species' range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established. The species benefits from pond creation programs in several areas of Central Europe. This is often a flagship species for numerous restoration programs. The species has been reintroduced to Latvia (Gaua National Park, Riga District) in 1987–1992 from Belarus and from captive bred individuals raised at Riga Zoo. In Sweden, a "restocking program" has successfully increased the population from 2,000 (1980) to 50,000 (2008) in about 900 breeding ponds and the species has been repopulated to its historic range.

There were 21 LIFE-projects, where the species is listed among conservation targets or results: https://webgate.ec.europa.eu/life/publicWebsite/search/get?basicSearchText=hyla+arborea

HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally associated with open, well-illuminated broad-leaved and mixed forests, bush and shrublands, meadows, gardens, vineyards, orchards, parks, lake shores and low riparian vegetation. Dark and dense forests are avoided. Subpopulations can tolerate periods of dryness and can be encountered in dry habitats (D. Cogălniceanu pers. comm. October 2008). Spawning and larval development takes place in stagnant waters such as lakes, ponds, swamps and reservoirs, and sometimes in ditches and puddles. The species has been reported from anthropogenic landscapes, including large cities. It sometimes occurs in sympatry with Hyla meridionalis (and produces infertile hybrids).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: While the species is common in suitable habitats in parts of its range, it is reported to be fragmented and in significant decline over much of its western European distribution (e.g. Fog 1995, Baker 1997, Gasc et al. 1997).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This is a widespread Palearctic species that is now considered to be endemic to Europe, from the Atlantic coast of France east to central parts of Poland, central Bulgaria, and Greece (throughout mainland Greece except the northeast, Euboea Island, Peloponnese, Crete, Ionian Islands, Thasos, Andros and possibly in other islands of Aegean Sea; Pafilis and Maragou 2020). This species is mostly absent from Scandinavia (except southern and eastern Denmark and extreme southern Sweden). The species had been introduced to the UK (the New Forest, southern England) but is now thought to be extinct there and is not mapped. This is a lowland species that has been recorded at a maximum altitude of 2,300 m asl (in Bulgaria), although this requires reconfirmation.

The previous taxonomic concept of this species occurred in Iberia (scattered subpopulations) and France, eastwards to western Russia and the Caucasian region, and southwards to the Balkans and Türkiye (except extreme eastern, southeastern parts). Following genetic analysis, Hyla molleri and H. orientalis have been elevated from subspecies level to distinct species (Stöck et al. 2008). Subpopulations from Spain and Portugal have now been allocated to H. molleri, and subpopulations from Türkiye, Romania and eastern Poland, Ukraine to southwestern Russia, northern Armenia, Iran (Gilan, Mazandaran and Golestan provinces), and Azerbaijan have been allocated to H. orientalis (Stöck et al. 2008).

ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is quite sensitive to changes in habitat, including loss and fragmentation of forests, bush groves and meadows (with the isolation of subpopulations), which is thought to be caused by development and agriculture, and the drainage and pollution of wetlands (industrial and agricultural) and predatory fish species (such as Lepomis gibbosus). These impacts on metapopulations have led to declines in parts of Europe. The species is collected for the pet trade, and in some parts of its range (western Europe) this might be leading to local subpopulation declines. Intensification of local transport increases the number of road-killed individuals. Also, low genetic variability was detected in western and central European subpopulations which indicates their weak adaptive potential, and could consequently lead to poor conservation status (Dufresnes 2018).

One individual (from southern Montengro) out of 54 individuals (from Albania, Montenegro and Macedonia) tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) (Vojar et al. 2017). However, no declines were reported, and it is no known to what extent chytridiomycosis is a threat.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Given its recent designation as a species distinct from Hyla arborea, it is not specifically mentioned in conservation treaties as a distinct species. As a former subspecies of H. arborea, it is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive.

The species is protected by national legislation in several autonomous regions in Spain, it is recorded in Red Data books, and is present in many protected areas. In France, is is assessed as Vulnerable (B2ab(ii,iii,iv,v); UICN France et al. 2015) and it is protected by law (M. Berroneau pers. comm. February 2020).

Any measure of preservation of its favoured habitats or creation of new appropriate water bodies will increase population viability. As this species has a metapopulation structure, it is important to conserve terrestrial habitat to enable sufficient dispersion among local subpopulations as it exists in Parque Natural de los Arribes del Duero.

Spawning and larval development takes place in stagnant waters such as lakes, ponds, swamps and reservoirs, and sometimes in ditches and puddles. It sometimes occurs in sympatry with Hyla meridionalis (and produces infertile hybrids; Oliveira et al. 1991, Barbadillo and Lapeña 2003).

Martínez-Solano pers. comm. August 2019). Populations in arid parts are declining because of habitat destruction, especially because of desiccation of their breeding sites, application of chemicals for agricultural purposes and introduction of exotic species.

Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) is a possible threat to this species, and has been detected in its congener Hyla arborea (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in many protected areas, and strictly protected or protected by national legislation over much of its range. It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. The species is recorded in a number of national and sub national Red Data Books and Lists. It is considered Vulnerable in Czech Republic (Chobot and Nemec 2017), Slovenia (Anonymous 2010), Hungary (Halpern et al. 2019), Romania (Botnariuc and Tatole 2005), Bulgaria (Golemanski ed. 2011) and Greece (Legakis and Maragou eds. 2009), Near Threaten in Austria (Gollmann, 2007), Data Deficient in Albania (Anonymous 2013). New breeding sites for the species have been created in parts of its range (e.g., Hungary KEHOP-4.1.0-15-2016-00058). In parts of this species range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

Conservation Needed
Conservation measures needed include the end of introduction of stocking with fish fry and removal of predatory fishes in mountain lakes and ponds, reduction of overgrazing in mountain pastures, and the restoration of traditional livestock troughs which can serve as breeding sites. The preservation of satellite pools is essential around fish lakes to maintain the species (Denoël et al. 2016).

There is an urgent need to conserve the unique paedomorphic mountain isolates of Ichthyosaura alpestris (Denoël et al. 2005, 2009, 2019) For instance, all paedomorphic endemics from Montenegrin mountain lakes have now disappeared (Denoël et al. 2019).

The preservation of satellite pools is essential around fish lakes to maintain the species (Denoël et al. 2016). There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Further research is required on the full effects of Bsal and other emerging pathogens on this species.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a mostly aquatic species that is generally found close to water. It is widespread in both alpine and lowland habitats including wet, shaded coniferous, mixed and deciduous forests, sub-alpine meadows and pastureland. It can be found in slightly modified habitats, although it is less common in large cultivated fields. The species breeds, and larval development takes place, in stagnant waters (except large lakes) including shallow ponds, temporary pools, lakes, bogs, ditches, drinking troughs, ruts and sometimes slow-moving streams. Adults can shift ponds during the breeding season (Kopecky et al. 2010). Particularly, they leave fished ponds to join fish free ponds when available at close proximity (Winandy et al. 2017). The generation length can vary between 2–10 years depending on the locality. The species life expectancy might be up to 20 years, but is on average around 7–13 years (Miaud et al. 2000). Several dozens to hundreds of eggs are deposited per female each year. Paedomorphic subpopulations occur almost exclusively in southern Europe (in mountain lakes of Slovenia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Italy and France).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is generally common in suitable habitat. The species is considered to be rare in Hungary and Bulgaria; threatened in Austria and Denmark; vulnerable in Spain (Ichthyosaura alpestris cyreni) and endangered in Ukraine (S. Litvinchuk, pers.comm.). Local declines have been observed in Italy, Albania and Montenegro, due to fish introductions, however, it is still observed in good numbers (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019; R. Duguet and S.N. Litvinchuk pers. comm. October 2022). Broad-scale declines have been shown in Montenegro (Denoël et al., 2019). Ichthyosaura alpestris inexpectata, endemic to a restricted range of southern Italy, is seriously threatened by the recent introduction of allochthonous fishes (since 2017 carps and since 2019 mosquitofishes) in two of the five sites of presence, and for this reason this subspecies is considered Endangered at national level (I. Bernabò, S. Tripepi, A. Romano pers. comm. October 2022).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is found throughout much of Europe, ranging from the French Atlantic coastline eastwards to the Ukrainian Carpathians, Romania, and Bulgaria and widely distributed in the Balkans, south to Greece (Pindos in northern Greece, western Central Greece and in north Peloponnese; E.-A. Toli, Greece national Red List). Isolated subpopulations are present northern Poland (Gdansk), southern Italy and northern Spain, but it is absent from Portugal. The distribution map is based largely on Denoël et al. (2001). The species occurs from sea level to around 2,500 m asl (Switzerland and French Alps).

It has been introduced in other parts of Europe, outside of its native range, e.g. in the United Kingdom and in the Sierra de Guadarrama (Madrid Province, central Spain), and has also been introduced to New Zealand (Arntzen et al. 2016).

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is vulnerable to fish introduction and breeding habitat destruction (drainage of wetlands and aquatic pollution) throughout its range (Denoël and Ficetola 2008). Following fish introductions, most populations rapidly become extinct (particularly alternative paedomorphic populations); some taxa (if taxonomy justified) have disappeared following fish introductions (e.g., Ichthyosaura alpestris lacustris (Denoël et al. 2005, 2009, 2019). Forestry activities and traffic by tourists are threatening breeding populations using track pools on forestry roads (Harmos and Magos 2021). In the Balkan countries, an additional threat is the development of “run-of-river” mini-hydroelectric power stations (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021). In some areas it is collected in excess for use in education and science (this has led to the extinction of the species from some Ukrainian localities). It is also collected in small numbers for the commercial pet trade (especially I. a. inexpectatus of Calabria). Subpopulations in the Peloponnese and southeastern continental Greece are facing severe habitat loss.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis ( Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that this species is moderately susceptible to infection, however, mortality rate varied by dosage with high dosages resulting in high mortality and low dosages with low mortality (Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). Thus, it may be a threat to this species but further research is required to determine the full effects.

Alpine newt is also susceptible to Ranavirus infection (Balsiero et al. 2009) and Amphibiocystidium-infection was detected in laboratory conditions in Switzerland (Oevermann et al. 2007).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: In some areas there is over-collection of the species for use in education and science (this has led to the extinction of the species from some Ukrainian localities). It is also collected in small numbers for the commercial pet trade (especially Ichthyosaura alpestris inexpectatus of Calabria). It is presumed that all of these individuals are taken from the wild. Some subspecies are more impacted than others (Denoël et al. 2005, 2009).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention, and is protected by national legislation in Spain. It is present in Parque Nacional de las Islas Atlánticas de Galicia, Parque Nacional de Doñana and Parque Nacional de Cabañeros in Spain. In Portugal, it has been recorded from Peneda-Gerês National Park.

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Bsal monitoring should continue and if it is detected within this species' range, then it should be reassessed. Further research is required to delimit the distribution limits with Lissotriton maltzani.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a largely aquatic species, with vegetated shallow ponds and streams being the preferred habitat. It may also be found in cattle troughs, lagoons, streams and deep still waters, and is frequently found in temporary ponds. Animals have also been recorded from irrigation channels and other human-made ephemeral or permanent structures (C. Ayres, pers. comm.). The importance of lotic aquatic sites for this species was demonstrated by de Vries and Marco (2017). The species occupies a diverse range of terrestrial habitats including eucalyptus plantations, pine groves, open oak (Quercus) woodland, scrub and sandy coastal areas. The species may be found in traditionally farmed areas. It breeds by larval development.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is relatively common in suitable habitat throughout its range, although subpopulations in central Spain (Madrid and Castilla la Mancha) are reported to be rapidly decreasing. It is more common towards the west of its range, and is considered to be more common in western Spain and is less common to the east (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021). Subpopulations in Madrid and Castilla la Mancha seem to have strongly declined since 2000 (AHE 2021), probably because of habitat loss and the negative effect of exotic species (e.g. crayfish species Procambarus clarkii; Díaz-Paniagua 2014). While it is tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is restricted to the western part of the Iberian Peninsula, where it occurs from sea level to elevations approaching 1,870 m asl, but is mostly present between 400–1,000 m asl.

Following ongoing taxonomic work, subpopulations from southwestern Portugal are now recognised as Lissotriton maltzani (Sequiera et al. 2020, Speybroeck et al. 2020). The range is largely well delineated at the broad scale, although some parts of the contact zone with L. maltzani need to be finely delineated with molecular markers (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).
RedListRationale.value: Bosca's Newt (Lissotriton boscai) is a European endemic species restricted to the western Iberian Peninsula. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is mostly threatened by the loss of breeding pools caused by drainage for agriculture and urbanisation. Some mortality in this species through disease (iridovirus) has been recorded in Carris Lake, Peneda-Gerês National Park, Portugal. This disease might be non-native and is thought to have been transferred to the lake by an introduced predatory fish (Lepomis gibbosus). The species is also susceptible to Ranavirus (Price et al. 2014). Predation by introduced fish and other introduced species (such as crayfish [Procambarus clarkii] and mink [Mustela vison]) is also a threat to Lissotriton boscai. However, in much of its range, the species is resilient and its subpopulations are stable.

While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013. Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). While there is no Bsal currently known to be present within its' range, although it is present in Spain, this could be considered a potential threat to this species and it may need to be reassessed if the fungus is detected closer.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in a number of protected areas. It is included in national legislation in Bosnian Federation, Montenegro, Albania and Serbia under the name Triturus vulgaris, and is categorised as Vulnerable in the National Red Book of Bulgaria (Tzankov and Popgeorgiev 2015) and categorised as Endangered in North Macedonia (Sterijovski and Arsovski 2019).

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission. Moreover given the increased rate of fish introductions, new evaluations and conservation managements are urgently needed.

Certain conservation actions should focus on the few reported subpopulations that exhibit facultative paedomorphosis as they are declining at a higher rate than metamorphic populations and are at the edge of extirpation due to fish introduction (Denoël et al. 2009, 2019).

Research Needed
Bsal monitoring should continue and if it is detected within this species' range, then the species should be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species can be found in various habitats, including both deciduous and coniferous forests (consisting of beech, pine, oak etc.), their edges and meadow glades; also in some sub alpine areas. Reproduction and larval development occur in almost all temporary and permanent water sources, including lakes, ponds, swamps, springs, puddles, ditches, and overgrown stream pools. It may be present in modified habitats (Arnold and Ovenden 2002, Denoël 2004).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species mostly occupies Mediterranean and sub-Mediterranean parts of the western, southern and southeastern Balkan countries, and can be common in suitable habitats. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to the parts of western, southern and south-eastern Balkans, where it is found along the Dalmatian coast of central Croatia, south through Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, southern Kosovo, North Macedonia, Albania and Greece. It occurs between 0–1,842 m asl [between 4–1,475 m asl in the EU 27] (Wielstra et al. 2018).

The EOO is approximately 150,000 km2 (approximately 80,000 km2 for the EU27). Its approximate AOO, based on 269 sites from seven countries visited by Wielstra et al. (2018), is 1,076 km2 (332 km2 for the EU27). However, although exhaustive, this study did not include all subpopulations from Croatia, Herzegovina or Serbia, so it is considered likely that the full AOO exceeds 2,000 km2 (for the EU27 the AOO is perhaps above 500 km2, and perhaps close to 2,000 km2).

This European endemic species is restricted to the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe. It is assessed as Least Concern globally in view of its wide distribution (extent of occurrence (EOO) is approx. 150,000 km2), presumed large population, and supposed tolerance of a broad range of habitats. However, there is evidence that, in some large parts of the range, it is declining fast due to anthropogenic alterations (Denoël et al. 2009, 2019), which are generally progressing (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022). Particularly, several well-known populations are now extirpated following fish and crayfish introductions, with sub-population loss evidenced as up to 48% in Montenegro over the last two decades from a subset of localities surveyed over time (Denoël et al. 2019). Therefore if substantial conservation measures are not applied urgently, it will most probably qualify for listing in a threatened category. Additionally, approximate area of occupancy (AOO) based on 269 sites (including historical populations now extinct) from seven countries listed by Wielstra et al. (2018) is 1,076 km2 which would qualify this species for VU B2ab(iii), but, although exhaustive, this study certainly did not include all subpopulations from Croatia, Herzegovina, Serbia or Albania, so it is reasonable to suppose that the AOO is above 2,000 km2. Moreover, subpopulations are still not severely fragmented in regard to IUCN criteria, although they are in continuous decline in habitat quality (pollution, drying out, introduction of alien species- fish, etc), so this species does not qualify for a threatened category at present.

In the EU27 Member States, the species is restricted to Croatia, Bulgaria and mainland Greece and is assessed as Near Threatened (B2b(iii)) because, although the approximate AOO based on Wielstra et al. (2018) is 332 km2 for EU27 (which would qualify for EN B2ab(iii)), this study certainly did not include all subpopulations from Croatia, Greece and Bulgaria, so it is reasonable to suppose that the AOO is above 500 km2, and supposedly close to 2,000 km2 (which would support VU B2ab(iii)). However, although there is a continuous decline in habitat quality (pollution, drying out, the introduction of alien species - fish, etc), subpopulations still cannot be considered severely fragmented by IUCN criteria. It is therefore listed as Near Threatened. Conservation measures are needed to minimise threatening factors and prevent further negative anthropogenic impacts.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Subpopulations in Montenegro have declined due to the introduction of predatory fish species (Denoël et al. 2019). More recent introductions of crayfish is also likely an additional threat, often superposing to that one of fish, both taxa being sometimes even introduced in the same waterbodies (Denoël et al. 2019). There is evidence of climate change which is resulting in the increase of average air temperature and change of annual precipitation dynamics in parts of the western (Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro, Albania), southern (Greece) and south-eastern Balkans (Bulgaria), and there is general destruction of small water bodies due to urban, commercial and tourist development, at least in the countries of the western Balkans (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022). Subpopulations of Greek newts were found to be affected by such climate change (Denoël et al. 2019). Over-collection of newts for education, science, and the pet trade is also considered to be a threat.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to some parts of Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). This species has not been tested and there have been mixed results in susceptibility testing with its congeners, so it is unknown whether Bsal and the resulting disease will be a major threat to this species.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There is a note, however without source, that this species is collected for education and scientific purposes, as well as for the pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and Lists, and is present in many protected areas. It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and is protected by national legislation throughout its range. Restoration of a pond network in northwestern France revealed positive effects on local subpopulations of this species (Isselin-Nondedeu et al. 2017).

Paedomorphic phenotypes of Palmate Newts are declining, particularly following fish introductions (Denoël et al. 2005; Denoël and Ficetola 2014). Most populations are also clustered in a small geographic region (Larzac), what could accentuate the threat on their populations (Denoël, 2007; Denoël and Ficetola 2015)
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is present in lowland marshes, heathlands, moorlands, forests (where it may be very common), pastures and agricultural land. It is generally less abundant in cultivated areas, but it survives well in some anthropogenic habitats such as gardens. Ecological thresholds have been identified, showing the positive effect of forests and the negative effect of cultivated areas (Denoël and Ficetola 2007). Breeding and larval development takes place in a wide variety of small stagnant waters (including very small and acidic ponds, ditches and ruts), or (rarely) slow-moving waters.

Both sexes mature in three years; males live for nine years and females up to eight years (Amat et al. 2010).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is very common in suitable habitats over much of its range. It is endangered in the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg (Gasc et al. 1997), has been reported declinining in several European countries (Denoël, 2012) and uncommon (with a fragmented range) in northern Portugal and declining in parts of Spain (especially the southern subpopulations of Aragón, Castilla and León Provinces and the Ebro River subpopulations of Zaragoza and Tarragona Provinces).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to western Europe, where it occurs from northern Spain and Portugal (where subpopulations are often very fragmented), much of the United Kingdom (NBN 2023), Jersey, Guernsey and Isle of Man, western parts of Germany, France, Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg, also the extreme western Czechia and northern Switzerland. The subspecies Lissotriton helveticus punctillatus is known from a single locality, Pozo Negro, in Burgos province, Spain. An isolated subpopulation in extreme southeastern France is extinct. It occurs from sea level up to at least 2,400 m asl (in the Pyrenees Mountains).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The Palmate Newt (Lissotriton helveticus) is endemic to the European region, and is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU 27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population. However, regional declines have been highlighted (Denoël 2012).
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is locally threatened by general drainage, pollution and eutrophication of breeding pools, abandonment of traditional farming practices. The introduction of fish has been shown to reduce abundance of Palmate Newts in ponds (Denoël and Lehmann 2006) whereas fish removal caused Palmate Newt resilience (Denoël and Winandy 2015). Similarly, introduced crayfish are impacting populations. Alien fish introduction leads to forgoing aquatic life and thus decrease of reproduction (Winandy et al. 2015). It also negatively affects Palmate Newt foraging in aquatic habitats when species coexist (Winandy and Denoël, 2015). Desertification is a threat in southern parts of the range, and climate change/fluctuation is a general threat to reproductive success and population stability (Galloy and Denoël 2010, Meek, 2021). Road kills present another significant threat for this species (Meek 2012), and rural road networks act as barriers to gene flow for this species (Garcia-Gonzalez et al. 2012). Dermocystic infections have also been recorded in this species in several places (Gonzales-Hernandez et al. 2010, Courtois et al. 2013, Galán and Dopereiro 2017, Martínez-Silvestre et al. 2017), as well as triple co-infections (Ayres et al. 2020), which could erode population stability in the long-term. Individuals have also tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) (Lastra González et al. 2019), but it is unknown to what extent this is a threat to this species.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that this species is resistant to infection (Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021), and it is not considered to be a major threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
The species is considered Critically Endangered in Czechia. It is not considered threatened in Romania, but was proposed as 'Rare' following earlier IUCN criteria (Gasc et al. 1997). The draft Carpathian Red List of threatened amphibians (Urban and Kautman 2014) considered the species to be Vulnerable.

Conservation Measures In-Place
This species is present in a large number of protected areas. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and is included in the Habitats Directive of the European Union (Council Directive 92/43/EEC), in Annex II i.e. species of community interest whose conservation requires the designation of special areas of conservation and Annex IV, i.e. species that require a strict protection regime, both within and outside Natura 2000 sites. It is listed in the Red Data book of Ukraine.

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species can be found in wet and shaded coniferous, mixed and deciduous forests (consisting of beech, alder, pine, oak etc.), their edges and meadow glades; also sub alpine areas. Reproduction and larval development occurs in almost all temporary and permanent water sources in the Carpathians including lakes, ponds, swamps, springs, puddles, ditches, overgrown stream pools and even wheel ruts in country roads. It may be present in modified habitats, even polluted waters (Arnold 2003). In traditionally managed habitats, this species usually utilises the flooded pastures or small ponds formed in or near dirt roads for reproduction, resulting in high local densities (Gherghel et al. 2019).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is generally common, but it is not abundant in parts of the Carpathian Mountains. It is generally locally abundant in Poland. Due to decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and collection of individuals for science and the pet trade, the population is inferred to be locally decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to the east Carpathian and easternmost Sudetes Mountains, and is found in Czechia, Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Ukraine. There is a small introduced subpopulation in the Bayrischen Wald (Bavarian Forest) in Bavaria, Germany. It occurs between 120–2,000 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution (just in Romania, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is greater than 20,000 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is greater than 2,000 km2; Cogalniceanu et al. 2013), tolerance of a broad range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Some subpopulations have declined due to habitat destruction (logging and infrastructure development), introduction of predatory fish species (Bylak and Kukula 2009) and pollution of habitats by domestic sewage. In the Ukrainian Carpathians, subpopulations are exposed to the negative impacts of climate change, intensive tourism, disturbance of vegetation cover at the bottom of water-bodies (Kyyak et al. 2021). Collection of newts for education, science and the pet trade has negatively impacted some subpopulations. It is affected by prolonged hybridisation with its' closely related species Lissotriton vulgaris, wherever their parapatric ranges meet around the Carpathians (Litvinchuk et al. 2003; Zielinski et al. 2014). This is mostly at lower elevations, as the range of L. vulgaris is generally shifting in the region with ongoing deforestation. This species hybridises with L. v. ampelensis within the Carpathian Basin in Transylvania and with L. v. vulgaris outside the Carpathian basin (Zieliński et al. 2019). The long history of genetic exchange in multiple, spatially and temporally distinct introgression events resulted in complete mtDNA replacement in this species with L. vulgaris mtDNA (Zieliński et al. 2013).

Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). It is unknown what this species' susceptibility will be to Bsal as laboratory trials have not been carried out on this species to date (A. Martel and F. Pasmans pers. comm. June 2021). It may have some resistance based on its relation to its congeners, L. helveticus and L. vulgaris, which demonstrate some resistance in laboratory trials (A. Martel and F. Pasmans pers. comm. June 2021) but further work is required. There is no Bsal currently known to be present within its' range, but it may be a potential future threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is collected for education, science and the pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within many protected areas. It is listed in Appendix II of the Bern Convention (as Pelobates syriacus). In the European Union it is protected under the Habitats Directive (Council Directive 92/43/EEC) included (as P. syriacus) in Annex IV (Animal and plant species of community interest in need of strict protection). It is considered Critically Endangered in Serbia, although the population trend is unknown (Kalezić et al. 2016). On the Red List of North Macedonia (Sterijovski et al. 2019) this species (included as P. syriacus) is considered Vulnerable (B2ab(i,ii,iii,iv)c(ii,iii,iv)).

Conservation Needed
Conservation recommendations are focused on habitat restoration, diminishing the effects of fragmentation, reducing mortality due to excessive pesticide use, pollution and road kills and most of all, education activities. Among the proposed measures are creation of ecological corridors between severely fragmented habitats and between protected areas where the species occurs; support of landowners in reducing pesticide use/ transitioning towards ecological agriculture, planting hedges along the edges of agricultural plots; adapting the road infrastructure by creating wildlife passages, when roads are in close vicinity (0–500 m) to wetlands or known breeding sites and maintenance of existing ponds or creation of new aquatic habitats for breeding.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
It is a habitat specialist which requires soft soil due to its burrowing ecology. Typical terrestrial habitats include sandy areas, floodplains, heathlands and deciduous forests with loose soil. It can take advantage of agricultural fields and irrigation canals near their natural habitats, due to the availability of friable soils and breeding sites (Székely et al. 2013). The spawning habitats include a variety of shallow permanent, semi-permanent and even temporary ponds. Larvae can tolerate water salinities up to 6 ppt, but growth and survival are impaired (~40% survival rate and smaller size), and cannot survive concentrations of >9 ppt (Stănescu et al. 2017).

Adults are explosive breeders. Sexual maturity can be attained at earliest after the first two years of terrestrial life (Cogălniceanu et al. 2014). The highest lifespan in adults was recorded in Serbian subpopulations (16 years old, Rot-Nikčević et al. 2001). The aquatic stage can last between 3–6 months (Cogălniceanu et al. 2000), which makes larvae highly vulnerable to pond desiccation and changes of the water chemistry.

Although it has a similar ecological niche as Pelobates fuscus, it is better adapted to pond desiccation (Székely et al. 2010) and water salinity (Stănescu et al. 2017). This species is also larger and has a longer lifespan compared to P. fuscus (Cogălniceanu et al. 2014), which may become an advantage when competing for resources.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is a cryptic, elusive species due to its burrowing habits and nocturnal activity, which is why its distribution range and population size are not well known. In Greece the majority of populations are small and very localised, isolated from one each other, the total range is fragmented and from Larissa town to the South, almost all historical known populations (by Sofianidou) are now extinct; the species is one of the currently most vulnerable and threatened amphibians in Greece (I. Strachinis pers.comm. November 2022).

It is often syntopic with Pelobates fuscus at the northern limit of the range – along the Danube floodplain, Danube Delta and Black Sea coast. Danube Delta Biosphere Reserve probably hosts one of the largest known subpopulations of this species throughout its range (Cogălniceanu et al. 2013).
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Following taxonomic revision of Pelobates syriacus (Dufresnes et al. 2019), this species is now considered to be endemic to Europe, where it occurs in Serbia, Romania, North Macedonia, eastern Albania (from a single locality), Bulgaria, Greece and European Türkiye (Sillero et al. 2014, Dufresnes et al. 2019a,b). Its present range is bounded by the Pannonian Plain and the Danube River area in the north, the Morava River valley in Serbia in the west, the Black and Marmara Seas in the east and the Mediterranean in the south (Cogălniceanu et al. 2013, Sillero et al. 2014, Dufresnes et al. 2019a,b). The range of the species is disjunctive since, apart from the main distribution, it also occurs in the lowlands of the northeastern portions of Serbia (post-Iron Gate area), the Timok River valley, presumably up to Knjaževac (ǅukić et al. 2008), and in the Western Plain of Romania (Teran et al. 2017). Patchy records extend the species’ range limits further north in the western and eastern parts of Romania (Székely et al. 2013, Teran et al. 2017).

Subpopulations in southern Greece (Peloponnese) were assigned to Pelobates balcanicus chloeae by Dufresnes et al. (2019a), but because the Global Amphibian Assessment does not assess subspecies, these records are retained in this assessment.

It occurs between 0–920 m asl, but is most common in lowlands and hilly areas, up to 400 m asl (Kalezić et al. 2015). Due to its secretive life, its distribution range is still not well known and might occur more widely (Valakos et al. 2008).

Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The Balkan Spadefoot is a European endemic species. It is assessed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states due to its wide distribution and large population, which is not thought to be decreasing at rates warranting a higher listing at this time.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
As a fossorial species, it is sensitive both to the composition and quality of soil, and to water availability for reproduction. The limited dispersal abilities and long larval period makes this species vulnerable to both terrestrial habitat degradation and fragmentation and degradation of aquatic habitats. Thus, the main threat is habitat alteration due to expanding agriculture, urban and industrial zones. Severe fragmentation of its habitats due to extensive agriculture and urbanisation is already reflected in its patchy distribution and might ultimately lead to local population isolation and decline. Since the aquatic stage is long the quality of the breeding ponds is essential for its reproductive success. Pollution of the breeding ponds can pose a serious threat to reproductive success and juvenile fitness. The main source of pollution is modern intensive agriculture, with heavy loads of pesticides and fertilisers leaching into aquatic habitats or accumulating in the soil, thus affecting both the aquatic and terrestrial habitats of the species. Increased salinity from agriculture, road de-icing and sea level rise can alter the available breeding habitats and thus impact reproductive success. Road mortality due to traffic can pose a serious threat, especially during mass migration events – in the spring, when adults head towards the breeding ponds, and in summer, when juveniles disperse from the breeding ponds throughout the surrounding habitats (Stănescu et al. 2016).

Climate change is a possible future threat for this species, especially regarding the availability and duration of temporary ponds used for breeding and the threat of severe floods that can cause massive mortality in floodplain subpopulations.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in a number of protected areas, including several NATURA 2000 sites, and is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in Spain, and is listed in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books. In France, the creation of new ponds or replacement on destroyed ones has worked well to maintain and increase suitable breeding habitats (P.A. Crochet pers. comm. 2022)

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required. The creation of new ponds and replacement of destroyed ones is needed throughout the species' range.

Research Needed
Population monitoring is required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The burrowing habits of this species generally restrict its distribution to areas with sandy or soft soils. It occurs in dunes, oak or pine forests, scrub, cultivated land, alluvial terraces and open areas, sometimes close to human habitation. In France it is largely restricted to coastal regions and continental floodplains. It breeds in temporary ponds, livestock ponds, and marshes, with a good vegetation cover, that occasionally may be slightly brackish (Thirion 2006, 2014), and occasionally in intermittent streams or oxbows. The larval development is completed in five to six months, requiring temporary ponds with long hydro-period for successful reproduction, which makes it vulnerable to introduced predators and desiccation of ponds.

The species seems to be very sedentary, resulting in marked genetic structure at low spatial scales. They can live for over 10 years (Talavera 1990), and their generation length is thought to be seven years (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. June 2020).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally common in suitable habitat. However, population declines have been observed in most of its range including the isolated subpopulations in western France (J.-M. Thirion pers. comm. March 2020), and it is believed that the population of this species has declined by at least 30% in the last 21 years (which is three generation lengths of this species; I. Martinez-Solano and R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species occurs across most of the Iberian Peninsula except the northern area of the peninsula and parts of central and northern Portugal, and extends to the Atlantic coast of western France and the Mediterranean coast of southern France. There are also isolated subpopulations on three Atlantic islands: Oléron, Ré and Noirmoutier (Thirion 2002a). It occurs from sea level (France and Spain) up to 1,770 m asl (Spain).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU A2ace) because of a population decline, estimated to be 30% over the past 21 years (three generations), inferred from the combined impact of habitat loss and degradation, and the effects of introduced species.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: In Iberia, threats include the isolation of subpopulations by agricultural intensification, destruction of wetland habitats (by urban development) and their pollution (with agrochemicals), and introduction of predatory Louisiana Crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) and fish (such as Gambusia holbrooki, Lepomis gibbosus, Micropterus salmoides and Ameiurus melas) to breeding areas. Mortality on roads, and tourism development, are causing localised declines in some subpopulations. Embryos have been shown to be susceptible to infection by Saprolegnia diclina and S. ferax (Fernández Benéitez et al. 2011). In France, urbanisation, road development (between terrestrial and aquatic habitats), wetland drainage, predatory Louisiana Crayfish, and an increase in oyster and fish farming producers which changes salinity levels and marine submersion are the principal threats to this species (Thirion 2002b, 2002, 2006, 2014; Thirion and Cheylan 2012, Priol 2015, Durand 2015). Overall, the severity of the threats to this species appears to be increasing.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in many protected areas, and protected by national legislation in most countries in its range. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and there is an Action Plan for this species in the Bern Convention. It is listed on Annex IV and Pelobates fuscus insubricus is listed on Annex II of the EU Natural Habitats Directive as a priority species. The species is recorded in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books and Lists (e.g. Near Threatened in Czechia - Chobot and Něměc 2017). In parts of this species' range, mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established. A conservation programme is in place for the isolated subpopulation in central France. An action plan was prepared by Andreone (2001) for the Italian subpopulations. Several EU LIFE projects were also dedicated strictly to this species for the restoration of habitats and increasing subpopulation sizes in Italy, Germany, Estonia and Denmark. It benefits from pond creation and responds well to habitat restoration (Rannap et al. 2009, Magnus and Rannap 2019). In Sweden 99% of the subpopulation was lost between 1959–1989, however, the species is now recovering due to reintroduction and population augmentation. It is subject to ex situ conservation breeding programmes in Germany (ten Hagen et al. 2016) and the Netherlands (Crombaghs et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Subpopulations benefit from pond creation and respond well to habitat restoration, and these actions should continue.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is mostly present in open areas, generally avoiding moist soils. It inhabits clear spaces in coniferous, deciduous and mixed forests (and their edges), groves, steppes, fields, meadows, sand dunes, heath land, gravel pits, parks and gardens. It may occur in modified habitats such as rice fields (in Italy). It is a highly specialised burrowing and nocturnal species, with a narrow ecological niche. Due to their secretive behaviour (nocturnal activity, weak underwater breeding call and cryptic coloration) their life histories are not well documented, and overall there is a scarcity of information (Cogălniceanu et al. 2013). Spawning sites are mostly permanent, small still waterbodies including ditches, ponds and lakes.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is common and widespread in the European part of the former Soviet Union. It is generally common in Poland. However, subpopulations are reported to be declining or rare in some European countries (e.g. Italy, Sweden, Denmark, Slovenia, Hungary, Germany and Estonia (Lacoste and Durrer 1999, Džukić et al. 2005, Eggert et al. 2006, Red Data Book of Estonia 2008). In Italy, there have been major declines in the last 10 years caused by urbanisation, and the species is thought to be on the brink of local extinction there and is conservation-dependent (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). In the western parts of Germany the species major declines in the last 20 years are caused by intensification of agriculture (e.g. deep and frequent plowing; Schulte et al. 2016). It is extinct in Switzerland.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This is a lowland species found throughout much of the plains and hilly regions of Europe, including from eastern Netherlands, eastern Belgium and eastern France, east through Germany, Denmark, Sweden (northern limits) and Central Europe and Eastern Europe to Russia. In the east, the contact zone with Pelobates vespertinus is well delineated from the Kursk region in Russia to the Black Sea coast (Dufresnes et al. 2019). It ranges from sea level up to 675 m asl. There is a very isolated subpopulation in Argenton-sur-Creuse in central France, and another isolated subpopulation (the endemic subspecies, Pelobates fuscus insubricus) in the Po Valley of northern Italy.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic is listed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is sensitive to water quality and soil structure (Rannap et al. 2009). Tadpoles have a low tolerance to salinity, above 4‰ survival is impaired (Stănescu et al. 2013, Stănescu et al. 2017). Pollution of wetlands by industry, domestic sewage and agriculture (including eutrophication), drainage of breeding pools and introduction of predatory fishes and crayfish are major threats to the species. Alien fish species that can tolerate low levels of oxygen (e.g. mosquitofish, goldfish, Pumpkinseed Sunfish) represent an important threat to the survival of tadpoles. The species is also threatened by loss of terrestrial habitats due to transformation into arable land, reforestation urban development and transportation infrastructure development that increases mortality on roads [and off-road driving] (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Changes in land management also impact the species through intensification of agriculture (e.g. over-stocking of cattle, extensive use of pesticides and fertilisers), stocking with fish and over-use of salt as defrosting agent during winter. The species is also collected in small numbers for the pet trade.

Pelobates fuscus insubricus is a highly threatened subspecies. The existing subpopulations in northern Italy, that were previously considered as a distinct species, have suffered a strong decline recently. In some areas it is threatened by the introduced crayfish. Chytridiomycosis may also be a problem in the near future (if it is not already).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is collected in small numbers for the pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in a number of protected areas. The species is listed on Annex IV (animal and plant species of community interest in need of strict protection) of the EU Habitats Directive. In addition, the species is listed on Appendix III (protected fauna species) of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It is protected by national legislation in Italy. It is listed as Endangered (B2a,b(ii,v)) on the Swiss Red List (Schmidt et al. 2023).

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection and management is required for this species, including the control of invasive fish species.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is associated with lowland woodland and forest, and is sometimes found in slightly modified habitats (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. October 2019). It breeds in small stagnant waters (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. October 2019).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species is quite abundant in Italy. Subpopulations were reported to have declined in some alpine valleys in the 2004 assessment, however, recent surveys (2017-2019) did not reveal major declines and the species is still recorded in large numbers (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. October 2019). In other parts of northern Italy, subpopulations have declined due to habitat loss, water pollution, and the introduction of invasive alien fish (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. October 2019). Its population is thought to be relatively stable, but it may be experiencing some local declines due to local habitat loss and degradation.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is reported from mainland Italy and the island of Sicily (Italy), with smaller subpopulations present on the edge of its range in southern Switzerland (Ticino Canton) and western Slovenia (a single site on the Italian border), between sea level up to at least 1,855 m asl. Its presence is uncertain in Vatican City and San Marino.
