The Italian Tree Frog is endemic to Europe. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The species is potentially threatened by local habitat loss due to urbanisation and water pollution (presumably by agrochemicals), but overall it is not seriously threatened. Threats to this species in the Po Plain include habitat loss and agricultural pollution (Dufresnes et al. 2018). Invasive alien fish are also a threat to this species, especially within the (heavily impacted) Po Plain (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. October 2019).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is present in the Lake Skadar protected area, on the border of Montenegro and Albania, and presumably in several other protected areas of Albania. The species occurs in many protected areas throughout Greece (E.-A. Toli; Greek national Red List). It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a largely semi- and aquatic species, generally found in areas close to suitable open water wetland habitats but also far of water bodies, even in mountains (Jablonski pers. obs.). It breeds in various stagnant and slow-moving waterbodies. Introduced populations of this species in Italy do not form hybridogenetic hybrids with native species (T. Uzzell pers. comm.). Pelophylax kurtmuelleri lives sympatrically and often also syntopically, with endemic water frogs P. shqipericus and P. epeiroticus and occasionally hybridises with them (Hotz and Uzzell 1983, Schneider et al. 1984, Hotz et al. 1985, Sofianidou and Schneider 1989, Vucić et al. 2018). However, this hybridisation events seems uncommon (Papežík et al. 2021) and hybrids are rare.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species was considered by Gasc et al. (1997) to be common throughout its range. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the harvesting of individuals, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to Europe, where it is naturally distributed throughout much of Greece, Albania, and possibly part of southern Montenegro (not mapped). It is also known from southwestern Bulgaria (Lukanov et al. 2013). In Greece, the species distributed throughout mainland except Thrace region and also occurs in several Greek islands in Aegean and Ionian seas, as well as on Euboea, Thassos, Kithyra and Poros islands (E.-A. Toli; Greece national Red List).

It occurs between sea level to more than of 2,000 m asl in Albania (Szabolcs et al. 2017; D. Jablonski pers. data).

Records from Eastern Europe (southwestern Poland [Kolenda et al. 2017] and Kaliningrad Province in Russia [Litvinchuk et al. 2020, Svinin et al. 2021) are of uncertain origin, either introduced or the distribution may be a result of natural postglacial dispersions (D. Jablonski pers. data), and are excluded here following (IUCN SSC Amphibian Specialist Group 2022).

The species was also introduced to Imperia province, Liguria, northwestern Italy in 1941, where it is currently expanding its range (Lanza 1962, Lanza and Corti 1993). Further introduced populations are reported from France (Dufresnes et al. 2017), Switzerland (Dubey et al. 2014), Sardinia in Italy (Bellati et al. 2019), Slovenia (Bressi 2007), and possibly Croatia (Jelić et al. 2022). A record from Libya (Plötner 2005) is also considered to be introduced. None of the introduced range, except for Italy is mapped.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is listed as Least Concern both globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance to a range of habitats, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: It is locally common species but threatened in its native range by drainage of wetland habitats and aquatic pollution of many waterways caused by agrochemical and industrial (including mining) contaminants. In northern parts of its native range (e.g., Lake Skadar) it is significantly threatened by over collection for commercial purposes (consumption in local restaurants, international food industry). Individuals are collected by local people even during the breeding seasons (D. Jablonski pers. obs. 2015-2021). The species is additionally threatened by accidental introductions of commercially transported non-native water frogs. However, it remains abundant in many places.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is harvested for food on a commercial level.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive and Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is protected by national legislation in Serbia (Anonymous 2010). It occurs in a number of protected areas. The species has been assessed as Least Concern for Greece (E.-A. Toli, unpublished draft).

Conservation Needed
Improved management is required for the protected areas, in light of the extensive hydro-power development that is occurring within these areas (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019).

Research Needed
Population monitoring is recommended for this species.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a largely aquatic, montane species associated with cold, small, clear rivers, streams and springs often located in shady deciduous and mixed forest. It may also occur in moors and meadows, and around glacial pools in lakes. Breeding and larval development takes place in water with high concentrations of oxygen, therefore predominantly in fast running streams and rivers. It is presumed that the species can tolerate some slight habitat modification.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is reported to be generally abundant in medium to high-altitude areas, with fast-running water (Gasc et al. 1997), and remains relatively widespread in Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania and Greece (Kalezić and Dzukić 2001, Ioannidis et al. 2014, Szabolcs et al. 2017). The species is considered common in suitable habitats in medium and high-altitude areas throughout Greece (Pafilis and Maragou 2020).

Since 2010, there have been multiple initiatives to build mini-hydro power plant diversions on the mountain rivers of Balkan countries and across its range (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Diversion of waterflow from riverbeds to the tubes, with little or no water remaining, drastically changes species’ suitable habitat and directly jeopardizes development of spawns and later tadpoles. If the development of hydro-power continues at the same rate, along with other threats, it is reasonable to assume that the population will decline by at least 20% in the next 20 years (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Recent phylogeographic insights between populations (Šunje et al. 2018, Jablonski et al. 2021)report a very shallow level of intraspecific genetic variability through the Balkans, with two main, statistically supported lineages having a partly sympatric distribution. It suggests that the lineages of R. graeca probably diverged in a very narrow spatial and temporal window with subsequent rapid colonization, and possible extinction of peripheral populations, resulting in the observed low divergence between detected lineages and haplotypes (Jablonski et al. 2021).

Although the species is considered as environmentally plastic, more attention to this Balkan endemic frog is needed. According to characteristics of distribution, ecology and natural history, populations in Serbia are considered endangered (Urošević and Džukić 2015).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to the Balkans, ranging from the northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina (Šukalo et al. 2015), through western, central and southern Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania, most of mainland Greece, and east to southwestern and southern Bulgaria (Jablonski et al. 2021). The presence of the species in eastern Croatia (not mapped) is possible but not confirmed (D. Jablonski pers. comm. April 2023), and the species has not yet been confirmed for the western parts of the Thrace region of Türkiye (Kurnaz 2020, Jablonski et al. 2021). The species occurs between 200-2,000 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The Greek Stream Frog (Rana graeca) is a European endemic species. It is assessed as Least Concern globally in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population. Although the range is more restricted (Greece and Bulgaria) in the EU27 member states, it is thought to occur across much of mainland Greece and is considered Least Concern for the EU27 region. However, due to plans for extensive development of small hydro-power plants, the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat is expected to increase and this species' population should be monitored.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The major threat to this species is the loss of suitable habitat resulting from forest fires, wetland drainage, construction of dams, etc. It is also affected in some places by pollution from mostly small-scale agriculture and waste water pollution (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019). More than 4,500 small diversion hydro-power plants are in the planning phase in the Balkan Peninsula (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021). In 2019, 188 of those hydro-power plants were under construction, while another 1,004 plants were already operating, for which the building began from 2010, and 1,031 (or 37%) of the planned dams were projected to be built in protected areas with high protection status (118 of which were in national parks, 547 in Natura 2000 areas - see in Schwarz and Vienna 2017). Climate change may also be a future problem which will further compound the drying of the river habitats (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019).

In the EU27 region, the number of projected small hydropower plants in 2020 was 598 for Greece and 594 for Bulgaria (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021)
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Measures In-Place
This species has been recorded from Parque Nacional de Ordesa y Monte Perdido and Parque Nacional de Aigües Tortes y Lago San Mauricio, Spain, and presumably occurs in several other protected areas. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and it is protected by national legislation in Spain.

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: It is a largely aquatic montane species that inhabits cold mountain lakes, torrents, streams, and occasionally cave systems, that are ice-free for at least four months of the year (Griffiths 1996). The eggs are deposited individually under rocks and stones in well-oxygenated, cold streams with rocky bottoms, and the larvae then develop in these streams. This species has a small clutch size of 20–40 eggs (Griffiths 1996).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is abundant or common in parts of its restricted range, although several peripheral subpopulations have disappeared largely through loss of habitat. It is likely that the subpopulations that occur at lower elevations within its range are at higher risk of decline due to habitat loss (Valbuena-Ureña et al. 2018; I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. September 2019). It is more common in the west of its range.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species is found throughout much of the Pyrenean mountain range in France, Spain, and Andorra, where it occurs between 175 to over 3,000 m asl (on the northern slopes of the Pyrenees), although the average range is 700–2,500 m asl. It has recently been found in the Corbières Mountains, 20 km southeast of Carcassonne, in south-eastern France, which represents a range extension northwards.

EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

The Pyrenean Brook Salamander (Calotriton asper) is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The main threats to this species are loss and damage of its aquatic habitats. Infrastructure development and tourism lead to over-exploitation of water resources, including from skiing facilities. The introduction of predatory trout (salmonids) and other fishes is also a threat, leading to population extinctions, especially in mountain lakes. Pesticides are readily accumulated in the body tissues of this largely insectivorous species, and several populations demonstrate contamination by these chemicals (Gasc et al. 1997).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bdcan cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal demonstrate resistance to infection and subsequent disease for Calotriton asper (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). It is thought that wild subpopulations would have some resistance to Bsal and it is not considered to be a major threat to this species. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species will not be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years. Bd has been found in this species (Martínez-Silvestre et al. 2020), but it is unknown to what extent it may be a threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is presumed to occur in numerous protected areas. It is listed in a number of Red Data Books and Lists and is both listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and protected by national legislation in parts of its range. In parts of this species' range mitigation measures to reduce road kill have been established.

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.
Research Needed
Details on distribution range and contact zones with newly recognised species (former subspecies) are needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is generally associated with woodland habitats, including deciduous, coniferous, mixed forests and dry forests and woodlands. It is an adaptable species also present in meadows, bushlands, parks, fruit gardens, many damp habitats and rural and urban areas. The species breeds by larval development in still and slow moving shallow waters and irrigation ditches; females lay 200–300 eggs. It is often recorded from modified habitats. Several hybrids with Lissotriton helveticus have been reported while hybridisation with L. montandoni is quite common in syntopic populations. In Greece, parts of Bulgaria and Turkish Trace it occurs in small, relatively shallow ponds (up to 100 cm deep), connected to irrigation ditches, with still or very slow moving water and aquatic vegetation included reeds, flooded grass and a small amount of unidentified pond weed (Raxhworthy 1988). Terrestrial habitats include rough grassland, scrub and arable land (Raxhworthy 1988). It is very common among dense filamentous algae in drinking springs near roads (S.N. Litvinchuk and D.V. Skorinov pers. com. October 2022). Marmara region is an important industrial region in Türkiye. This factor affects natural habitats of this species negatively. In Thrace, intensive agricultural chemical use also affect local populations of this species negatively (N. Üzüm and K. Olgun pers. com. December 2022).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is very common or numerous over much of its range.

Between 1990–2000, it was found in good numbers in Italy, however it has been observed to have declined and disappeared due to crayfish invasion in the last 10 years in the lowlands of the country (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Due to habitat loss, it has lost 50% of its breeding habitat in the Po Valley, but subpopulations in higher elevations in Italy are not considered to be threatened and are stable at present (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Overall, it may be locally decreasing in this country.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is widespread through most of Europe (with the exception of the Iberian Peninsula, from which it is absent). It ranges from Ireland and Great Britain, through west and Central Europe and Scandinavia, south to Italy, the Balkans, and east through Ukraine and much of the steppes of European Russia. It occurs at elevations from sea level up to 2,150 m asl (Austria).

Following analysis, some subpopulations previously assigned to this species (including those from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Greece and Türkiye) have now been assigned to Lissotriton graecus, L. kosswigi, L. lantzi and L. schmidtleri (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009) retained the status of good species (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2009).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern for both Europe and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a broad range of habitats and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
There are no major threats to this species. Localised threats include general drainage, degradation of habitat and loss of breeding sites caused by both climate change and human alteration, as well as pollution and eutrophication of breeding sites (Sotiropoulos and Lymberakis 2015, Olgun and Üzüm 2015, Tzankov and Popgeorgiev 2015), destruction of small water bodies in the western Balkans (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022), logging of forest surrounding breeding pools, the introduction of predatory fishes and collection for the pet trade. A rapid local decline in the abundance due to the intensive growth of the city has been noted in the west of Istanbul, where it was common in the early 2000s (for example, Halkali and Küçükçekmece stations), and now it is extinct (S.N. Litvinchuk pers. com. October 2022). The species has been observed to have declined and undergone local extirpation in Italy due to crayfish invasion (Procambarus clarkii) in the last 10 years in lowland areas of the country (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Introduced fish Perccottus glenii strongly prey tadpoles of this species, causing strong decline in the number of local populations in Russia (Reshetnikov 2001).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that this species is somewhat susceptible to infection, however, it is thought that it may only suffer from low mortality rates as only one in four individuals died, while three out of four individuals cleared the infection Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). While Bsal is present within this species' range, it is not considered to be a major threat at present. Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species will not be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years. However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within or nearer to this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There is collection of this species for the national and international pet trade in Russia.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the El Montseny Natural Park. A captive breeding programme started in 2007 and is being carried out by the Departament de Medi Ambient of the Generalitat de Catalunya, Spain (Valbuena-Ureña et al. 2017a). The Life Tritó Montseny project (LIFE15 NATO/SE/000757) started on 1 October 2016 will promote around fifty actions to ensure the conservation of this endemic species and its habitat. The actions will be carried out primarily in the Montseny Natural Park and Biosphere Reserve, as well as in three breeding centres (http://lifetritomontseny.eu/en). 

Conservation Needed
Management actions are needed, including limiting the expansion of holm oak forest, for ameliorating the species' habitat (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. August 2019). There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Research is needed to determine the species' ecological requirements, and to determine management options. Population monitoring will also be important with the risk of Bsal.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species lives in oligotrophic and cold (below 15°C) streams, with very steep slopes and rocky beds of very cracked rocks, preferentially in beech forest (Fagus sylvatica) but also in Holm Oak forest (Quercus ilex), with patches of Common Alder Alnus glutinosa (Carranza and Amat 2005). Neither juveniles or adults have been found on land (Carranza and Amat 2005). If this behaviour is confirmed, the only way that contact among subpopulations could occur is by moving down one watercourse and then up other tributaries of the same river system, although this is very unlikely. It therefore seems possible that there is a considerable degree of isolation between the subpopulations.

Generation length has been estimated to be similar to its congener, Calotriton asper, which ranges between three (at lower elevations) to six (at higher elevations) years (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. August 2021).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
Its population is thought to number between 1,000–1,500 mature individuals, with an estimated rate of decline of 15% over the last 10 years. Preliminary demographic studies were carried out in two streams (Montori and Campeny 1991);in these streams, this species occurred at very low densities and in one stream it was extinct above 1,000 m asl. The population of this species is divided into two groups that occur on each side of a river valley. These two groups are genetically and morphologically differentiated (Carranza and Amat 2005, Valbuena-Ureña et al. 2017b). 

The disease chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging concern for salamanders in Europe (see Threats section). Extinction risk modelling for Bsal calculated the probability of extinction of this species in three generations based on a best and worse case scenario (see model in the attached Supplementary Information). The best case scenario was calculated using the minimum generation length estimate and the worst case scenario using the maximum generation length estimate. For this species the probability of extinction for the best scenario using a generation length of three years is 99.92%, and for the worst scenario using a generation length of six years is 99.99%. Applying criterion E (see spreadsheet; link in the Supplementary Information), this species qualifies for Critically Endangered, as it has a greater than 50% probability of extinction in the wild in three generations. Applying criterion A, the model also predicts that at least 80% or more of the population will be lost within three generation lengths [9–18 years] (see model in the attached Supplementary Information). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is already presently decreasing. Subpopulations are declining in the upper parts of all the streams as the water table is being lowered.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to the El Montseny mountain massif situated in north-eastern Spain. It's only been found in seven streams, which are divided into two groups (one with three subpopulations and one with four), most of which are isolated from each other. All subpopulations occur within the boundaries of El Montseny Natural Park (Carranza and Amat 2005). It is found between 600–1,200 m asl. It occurs in one threat-defined location, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 120 km<sup>2</sup>.
RedListRationale.value: Listed as Critically Endangered due to a projected population decline, estimated to be more than 80% over the next 9–18 years (which represents three generation lengths), from the potential impact of Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) on this species and from a deterioration in habitat quality as a result of water abstraction. Furthermore, extinction risk modelling for Bsal indicates that the probability of extinction for this species will be >50% in the next three generation lengths (9–18 years).
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The drying out of mountain streams is the most immediate threat to this species. Large amounts of water are being extracted from El Montseny, and this is bottled and sold widely in Spain and Europe. As a result, El Montseny is drying out and the distribution of this species is being reduced dramatically. The low population size of the species could also be due to past human alteration of its original habitat (Carranza and Amat 2005). The species might also be affected by global warming. All future scenarios projected a significant decrease in annual streamflow from 21% to as much as 67% (Ledesma et al. 2019) and the frequency and length of low streamflow events will dramatically increase. The beech (Fagus sylvatica) forest, an excellent habitat for this species, has shifted upwards by 70 m at the highest altitudes (1,600–1,700 m asl) since 1945, and is being replaced by Holm Oak (Quecus ilex) forest at lower altitudes (800–1,400 m) (Peñuelas and Boada 2003). In future scenarios the potential change in vegetation toward an expansion of holm oak forests will be more important than climate changes in determining threshold low flow conditions (Ledesma et al. 2019). In other words, the most favoured woodland habitat of the species is moving up into areas where the streams are drying out.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g., Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal demonstrate that Calotriton arnoldi is highly susceptible to the disease, and mortality has been observed in individuals of this species that have been tested Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). With a Bsal outbreak in Spain diagnosed at ca. 23 km from its range, this is a major threat to the species. Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling (see model in the attached Supplementary Information) has found this species to be at extremely significant risk from Bsal in the next immediate three years. Subpopulations have been screened for the presence of Bd, with negative results so far (Obón et al. 2013).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilized.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive and on Appendix II of the Bern Convention under Salamandra atra. It occurs in the following Natura 2000 sites: Orsiera Rocciavré (IT1110006), Val Troncea (IT1110080), Pra - Barant (IT1110032), Gruppo del Monviso e Bosco dell'Alevè (IT1160058), Vallée du Haut Guil (FR9312019), Haut Guil - Mont Viso - Val Preveyre (FR9301504). It is found in regional protected areas in both Italy and France [Parco Provinciale di Conca Cialancia, Parco del Monviso, Parco Naturale Orsiera-Rocciavrè, Parc Regional du Queyras and Réserve naturelle de Ristolas-Mont-Viso] (R. Manenti and F. Ficetola pers. comm. September 2019, D. Seglie pers. comm. May 2021).

Conservation Needed
There is a need to maintain traditional forest and alpine management within the species' range. There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Population monitoring will be important with the risk of Bsal.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is associated with rocky alpine meadows and scree slopes, often close to small streams, usually above the tree line. The known sites of this species at lower elevations may have mixed or coniferous forest. It gives birth to one to six fully metamorphosed young on land (Noellert and Noellert 1992), and is not associated with water. This species hides beneath rocks and stones when inactive and may be found in pastureland and other slightly modified habitats.

Generation length is conservatively estimated to be between 7–15 years.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is considered to be common, and some small known subpopulations of this species are considered to be relatively stable which has been verified through capture-mark-recapture studies (D. Seglie pers. comm. May 2021). However, slow declines have been observed in subpopulations in Italy (R. Manenti and F. Ficetola pers. comm. September 2019). The largest subpopulations in Italy (Germanasca Valley and Pellice Valley) have an estimated density of 733 and 548 individuals per hectare respectively (Eusebio Bergò 2001, De Michelis et al. 1999). The Germanasca Valley population was reduced during 2000 because of habitat changes caused by a destructive river flood which followed unusually high levels of precipitation. The other studied subpopulation in Italy is less abundant, with an estimated density between 100–400 individuals per hectare (Andreone et al. 2005, Bovero et al. 2001, Miaud et al. 2001, D. Seglie unpubl. technical reports 2017–2020). In other localities in Italy, it is less common and abundant than it is reported in the specific localities mentioned (R. Manenti and F. Ficetola pers. comm. September 2019). Due to ongoing localised decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and road mortalities, the population is inferred to be locally decreasing.

The disease chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging concern for salamanders in Europe (see threats section). Extinction risk modelling for Bsal calculated the probability of extinction of the species in three generations based on a best and worse case scenario (see model in the attached Supplementary Information). The best case scenario was calculated using the minimum generation length estimate and the worst case scenario using the maximum generation length estimate. For this species the probability of extinction for the best scenario using a generation length of seven years is 23.10%, and for the worst scenario using a generation length of 15 years is 99.89%. Applying criterion E, and using the midpoint of the range in probability of extinction from the extinction risk modelling (see link to spreadsheet in attached Supplementary Information), this species qualifies for Critically Endangered, as it has a greater than 50% probability of extinction in the wild in three generations.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species occurs only in a very small area of the western Alps on the border of Italy and France. It is distributed in the valleys of Po, Pellice, Germanasca and Sangone in Italy, and in the Guil Valley in France. It has also been reported to be present on the Maritime Alps, in Cuneo Province. This finding is based upon a single specimen housed in Florence Museum, and with a label indicating its provenance as "Antracque", which is a possible mistake for Entracque, Valdieri (Cuneo), Italy. The species has not been found again at Entracque or nearby sites. Ribéron (2003) concluded that the species' distribution is decreasing, but this assertion is based solely on the Entracque specimen. There is currently no reliable evidence of a reduction in the species’ range (D. Seglie pers. comm. May 2021). It occurs from 1,200 m (perhaps less) to around 2,600 m asl, but is found more commonly between 1,500–2,100 m asl (D. Seglie pers. comm. July 2021). The record of 2,800 m asl and corresponding locality (Lago delle Forciolline) is most likely erroneous (Andreone and Sindaco 1999, Vences et al. 2003, Andreone et al. 2004). This species may occur more widely in Italy, in Val Chisone which is located between the valleys of Sangone and Germanasca (D. Seglie pers. comm. May 2021).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is precautionarily listed as Critically Endangered because extinction risk modelling for Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) indicates that the probability of extinction for this species will be >50% in the next three generation lengths (21–45 years) [see attached Supplementary Information]. While this species has not specifically been tested for susceptibility to Bsal, it is presumed to be a problem, given high susceptibility of its closely related taxa Salamandra salamandra, among others.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
While there are no major threats to this species' habitat, some localized development for tourism might be disturbing the habitat. Road mortalities in Italy are also a localised but serious problem in Pian Del Re (Po Valley) and Conca del Pra (Pellice Valley). Other potential or identified threats to the species are changes in the hydraulic conditions of natural watercourses (Andreone et al. 2005).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Salamandra lanzai has not been tested for its susceptibility to Bsal, however, it is presumed to be a problem, given high susceptibility of its closely related taxa S. salamandra among others (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. October 2020). While Bsal is not present in this species' range, there is a risk from nearby outbreaks, with the nearest outbreak occurring 366 km away. Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species will be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 40 years. This does not take into account human introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilized.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is protected by law in several provinces in Italy, and it is listed in Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex II and IV of the EU Habitats Directive being considered as part of Salamandrina terdigita. It occurs in several protected areas, including most national parks in central and northern Apennines.

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is mainly found in forests with dense undergrowth in hilly and mountainous areas, often in north-facing mountain valleys. Only females of this species are aquatic during the short oviposition phase for which well-oxygenated waters, slow running streams (usually with rocky beds), drinking troughs, and residual and vernal pools in stream beds (sometimes of very small dimensions) are used. It appears to avoid seriously modified habitats. This species shows high site fidelity to breeding sites.

Generation length is conservatively estimated to be between 7–15 years.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is sometimes difficult to find, but it is common in western parts of its range. At some localities, it can be abundant and in suitable forest habitats subpopulations may reach densities of 600–1,600 individuals/ha (A. Romano pers. comm. September 2019). Due to ongoing localised decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be locally decreasing.

The disease chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging concern for salamanders in Europe (see Threats section). Extinction risk modelling for Bsal calculated the probability of extinction of the species in five generations based on a best and worse case scenario (see model in attached Supplementary Information). The best case scenario was calculated using the minimum generation length estimate and the worst case scenario using the maximum generation length estimate. For this species the probability of extinction for the best case scenario using a generation length of seven years is 0.7%, and for the worst case scenario using a generation length of 15 years is 52.69%. Applying criterion E, and using the midpoint of the range in probability of extinction from the extinction risk modelling (see link to spreadsheet in attached Supplementary Information), this species qualifies for Endangered, as it has a greater than 20% probability of extinction in the wild in five generations.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to peninsular Italy, mainly in the Apennine Mountains (where it is widespread), but also in other hilly areas to the west and east of the Apennines, north to the province of Caserta (Campania region) along the Tyrrhenian slope and north of Daunia Apennine along the Adriatic slope (south of this it is replaced by Salamandrina terdigitata). It is usually found at elevations between 200–900 m asl, but can occur between 50–1,500 m asl.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is listed as Endangered because extinction risk modelling for Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) indicates that the probability of extinction for this species will be >20% in the next five generation lengths (25–50 years) [see model in attached Supplementary Information]. While only juveniles have been tested, 100% mortality was observed.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
In parts of the species' range there are some localized declines through habitat loss and aquatic pollution. But overall, it is not significantly threatened.

However, this does not take into account human introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur within or nearer to this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: It is occasionally traded illegally for the pet trade (A. Romano pers. comm. September 2019).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in a number of protected areas (including several NATURA 2000 sites), and is recorded in several national and subnational Red Data Books and lists. It is also protected by national legislation throughout its range states (Gasc et al. 1997) and is listed on Appendix III of the Berne Convention.

Conservation Needed
In some areas protection of temporary ponds is a conservation priority for the species, and improved management of existing protected areas.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species' preferred habitats are dry or damp stony areas (including drystone walls). It is also observed in dunes, flooded quarries and cultivated areas. It is often present in calcareous or sandy areas. Occasionally, they can also be found in caves (I. Martinez-Solano pers. comm. June 2020). Aquatic habitats, where it breeds, include shallow, sunny, open (often ephemeral or temporary) waters, small pools, ditches and slow, small streams with a sandy substrate. It can occur in traditionally farmed areas.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is generally locally abundant over much of its range. The species is threatened in Italy due to loss of breeding sites which are usually small and isolated, thus more vulnerable to loss (S. Salvidio pers. comm. September 2019) on the edge of its range.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species was previously found in western Portugal, northern, central and eastern Spain, most of France (e.g. Sillero et al. 2014), and in coastal northwestern Italy (only in Ligury and southern Piedmont). In Portugal there is limited information on the distribution of this species in relation to Pelodytes ibericus. However, following genetic, morphological and acoustic analysis, the subpopulations from Portugal have now been assigned to Pelodytes atlanticus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017, Dufresnes et al. 2020). It occurs from sea level up to 2,000 m asl. Despite occurring near the border, it is considered to be absent from Luxembourg (M. Denoël pers. comm. June 2020).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Threats include drainage of marshland and canalisation of rivers (Gasc et al. 1997). Loss of suitable freshwater breeding habitats and habitat fragmentation are also threats. Intensification of agriculture is threatening the species in Iberia. Desertification is a threat in parts of its range (eastern Spain). Predation of larvae and adults by exotic fish and Louisiana Crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) introductions (especially in Iberia) is also a threat. Climate change may cause the loss of small temporary breeding sites due to reduction of precipitation and increase in air temperatures (S. Salvidio pers. comm. September 2019).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilized.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention and is protected by national legislation over much of its range. It occurs in many protected areas, and is listed in a number of national and sub national Red Data Books and Lists. Some subpopulations of this salamander are being monitored (e.g. central Spain, Zlote Mountains [southwestern Poland, East Sudety Mountains]). 

Bsal is included in Annex II of EU regulation 2018/1882 of the Animal Health Law, which means Bsal should be mitigated (the legislation explicitly mentions wild animals). However, mitigation efforts are currently not coordinated at an EU scale, and consist of mostly local initiatives which are currently limited to ex situ efforts [in the Netherlands] and preventing spread through informing the public [in Belgium and the Netherlands] (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. August 2021). There has been a single attempt to actively contain a Bsal outbreak (in northern Spain) using fencing, host removal, disinfection and perimeter surveillance but it is unknown to what extent this has been able to continue during 2020-2021 (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. August 2021).

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission. 

Research Needed
Further research is also required into the impacts of chytridiomycosis on this salamander.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is associated with wet cool deciduous, mixed, or rarely, coniferous forests with well shaded brooks and small rivers. Within the mountain forest belt, the species can be found in woodlands, glades and forest edges, rocky slopes, dense bush, and herbaceous vegetation. It is possible, that the occurrence of Salamandra salamandra on woodless mountain pastures and within hayfields indicates the past existence of forests. In the Iberian Peninsula the species may be found in upland Mediterranean type forest and associated habitats. The species prefers microhabitats covered with dense leaf-litter and moss. It does tolerate some habitat modification, and has even been found in gardens. In general, the female gives birth to well-developed larvae, that complete metamorphosis in streams, ponds and still waters. However, the subspecies, S. s. bernardezi and S. s. fastusa may give birth to two to eight fully metamorphosed young on land.

Generation length has been estimated to be 7–15 years.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
A number of large, stable subpopulations of this salamander exist in Central Europe. Some local subpopulation declines have been observed over parts of its range (e.g. through habitat loss, introduced predatory fish, and increased aridity in Spain). A severe decline has been reported in the Netherlands. Some local subpopulations have disappeared, and its population density has also been reduced in parts of Spain. In Italy, localized declines due to habitat loss have been observed in Apen (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the threat of Bsal, the population is continuing to decrease.

The generation length of this species is estimated to be between 7–15 years, and hence three generations is 21–45 years. It is conservatively estimated that Bsal will naturally advance at a rate of between 10–20 km per year. Therefore, a worst-case scenario of the impact of Bsal would be an outward spread of the disease from each current epicentre of 900 km (45 years at 20 km year), and the best-case scenario would be an outward spread of 210 km (21 years at 10 km year). In the attached map (see Figure 5 in Supplementary Information), the inner circle around each epicentre has a radius of 210 km, and the outer circle has a radius of 900 km and shows the modelled spread of the disease. When overlaid on the current range of the species, the best-case scenario has 15% of the range impacted, whereas the worst-case scenario has 70% of the range impacted (see calculations in Supplementary Information). A good estimate of the projected decline due to Bsal in the next three generations for this species is the midpoint of these two scenarios which is 42.5%. Habitat loss and degradation are also likely to contribute to this decline hence a conservation estimate is that the species will decline by between 30–49% in the next three generations which qualifies it for Vulnerable status.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This species is endemic to Europe, where it is present across much of central, eastern and southern Europe. In the former Soviet Union, it is only known from the mountains and foothills of the Ukrainian Carpathians. The subpopulations of this species in Iberia are very fragmented (there is a small area of occupancy within the wider extent of occurrence). It occurs from lowland areas up to 2,500 m asl (in central Spain).

Some subpopulations of Salamandra species reported from western Anatolia (Türkiye, not mapped) require further investigation and are coded as 'Presence Uncertain' until that has been done; there is at present no records of the species in Anatolia, though suitable habitat occurs there (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. October 2022).
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)

This species is considered to be endemic to Europe at present. It is assessed as Vulnerable (A3ce) both globally and for the EU27 Member States due to a projected population decline estimated to be greater than 30% over the next 21–45 years (which represents three generation lengths), from the potential impact of Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) on this species, and ongoing habitat loss and degradation that is occurring throughout its range.

A number of subspecies of Salamandra salamandra are restricted in range and may be considered to be threatened, in particular: S. s. longirostris in southern Spain (listed as Vulnerable in Spain), and S. s. bejarae-almanzoris in the mountains of north-central Spain (listed as Vulnerable in Spain).
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The principal threats include localized general habitat destruction, including the installation of run-of-river small hydropower plants throughout Balkan Peninsula (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2021), unsympathetic forest management, and pollution of breeding sites by agrochemicals, collection for commercial purposes (i.e. the pet trade), introduction of predatory species (salmonids and crayfish (Procambarus clarkii)) and population fragmentation. The mortality of adults on roads is a localized threat in some parts of its range. The presence of chytridiomycosis has been reported in some Spanish subpopulations.

UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is found in the pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas. In Portugal, it is present in Peneda-Gerês National Park where the population of Carris Lake has been severely impacted by disease. It is also protected by national legislation throughout its range (Gasc et al. 1997), and is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive and Annex III of the Bern Convention. Re-introductions and/or translocations of this species have been made in the area of Madrid, Spain.

Conservation Needed
There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Further research into the impacts of disease on this species is needed. In light of the threat of Bsal, the population should also be monitored especially if other outbreaks occur within its range.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
Aquatic habitats include well-vegetated ponds, pools, ditches and streams generally within dry woodlands, heathland, fields and rough grassland. It can occur in slightly modified habitats such as traditional farmland. Breeding and larval development take place in many different types of permanent and temporary water sources, usually with aquatic vegetation for reproduction.

Generation length is estimated to be 5–10 years (F. Pasmans pers. comm. July 2021).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is locally abundant in suitable habitats. It is locally endangered in central France, less threatened in southern France, and not particularly threatened in Portugal. In the 2008 assessment, it was reported to not be threatened in Spain. Since then declines caused by disease (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal)) have been recorded in Catalonia (Martel et al. 2020). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the effects of disease, the population is inferred to be decreasing. Extinction risk modelling for Bsal using subcriterion A3 predicts that at least 30% or more of the population will be lost within three generation lengths [15–30 years] (see the model in the attached Supplementary Information).

The generation length of this species is estimated to be between 5–10 years, and hence three generations is 15–30 years. It is conservatively estimated that Bsal will naturally advance at a rate of between 10–20 km per year. Therefore, a worst-case scenario of the impact of Bsal would be an outward spread of the disease from each current epicentre of 600 km (30 years at 20 km year), and the best case scenario would be an outward spread of 150 km (15 years at 10 km year). In the attached map (see Figure 5 in Supplementary Information), the inner circle around each epicentre has a radius of 150 km, and the outer circle has a radius of 600 km and shows the modelled spread of the disease. When overlaid on the current range of the species, the best case scenario has 10% of the range impacted, whereas the worst case scenario has 55% of the range impacted (see calculations in Supplementary Information). A good estimate of the projected decline due to Bsal in the next three generations for this species is the midpoint of these two scenarios which is 32.5%. Habitat loss and degradation are also likely to contribute to this decline hence a conservation estimate is that the species will decline by between 30–49% in the next three generations which qualifies it for Vulnerable status.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species is found in much of northern Iberia (mainland Spain and Portugal), and central, southern and western France. This species was introduced to the area of Turin, Italy, but is now presumed to be extinct there (J.W. Arntzen pers. comm.). It occurs from sea level to elevations approaching 2,100 m asl.

UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is found in the national and international pet trade.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in a number of protected areas over its range and protected by national legislation in several countries. It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. The species is considered Endangered in the Red Book of Czech Republic (Chobot and Něměc 2017), Switzerland (Schmidt and Zumback 2005) and Hungary (Halpern et al. 2019), as Vulnerable in Slovenia (Anonymous 2010), and as Near Threatened in Italy (Rondinini et al. 2013) and Croatia (Jelić et al. 2012). A European Action Plan was approved for the species complex by Bern Convention in 2006 (Edgar and Bird 2006). There have been 24 EC-funded LIFE projects that targeted either the species or its habitat (EC LIFE database).

In Slovenia and Croatia, this species has been included in monitoring projects (Jovanović and Jelić 2015, Stanković et al. 2015). The LIFE AMPHICON (LIFE18 NAT/SI/000711) project will mitigate four road sections for the species by the end of 2024. Supportive breeding is in place through this project. Restoration of current ponds and the creation of new ponds is underway in Slovenia and Italy (central Italy D. Salvi pers. comm. October 2022).

Conservation Needed
Monitoring is needed to substantiate Habitat Directive Article 17 reporting (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. October 2022). Water management should target the restoration of water bodies, serving as breeding habitats for the species throughout its range (B. Halpern pers. comm. October 2022). There is also an urgent need for an EU-wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed. For comparative reasons, baseline surveys should be undertaken; other emerging pathogens might need to be screened as well (B. Halpern pers. comm. October 2022). Long-term population and habitat studies are needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species occurs in a wide variety of terrestrial habitats from beech woodlands to arid Mediterranean climates, as well as modified habitats such as quarries. Its breeding and larval development take place in various stagnant permanent and temporary aquatic habitats; in Italy, stone wells and water tanks are key breeding sites (Romano et al. 2010, 2012).

Generation length is estimated to be 5–10 years (F. Pasmans pers. comm. July 2021).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
There are large subpopulations in the south of its range, with the species becoming less abundant in the north. It is still locally very abundant in Italy, but several subpopulations on the River Po plain are known to have become extinct. Major declines have occurred in the lowlands of Italy due to the impact of the invasive crayfish, Procambarus clarkii (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019; Falaschi et al. 2022). Subpopulations are declining generally in the Balkans.

The generation length of this species is estimated to be between 5–10 years, and hence the three-generation length period is 15–30 years. It is conservatively estimated that Bsal will naturally advance at a rate of between 10–20 km per year. Therefore, a worst-case scenario of the impact of Bsal would be an outward spread of the disease from each current epicentre of 600 km (30 years at 20 km year), and the best case scenario would be an outward spread of 150 km (15 years at 10 km year). In the attached map (see Figure 5 in Supplementary Information), the inner circle around each epicentre has a radius of 150 km, and the outer circle has a radius of 600 km and shows the modelled spread of the disease. When overlaid on the current range of the species, the best-case scenario has a very small part of the range impacted, whereas the worst-case scenario has 60% of the range impacted (see calculations in Supplementary Information). A good estimate of the projected decline due to Bsal in the next three generations for this species is the midpoint of these two scenarios which is just over 30%. Habitat loss and degradation are also likely to contribute to this decline hence a conservation estimate is that the species will decline by between 30–49% in the next three generations which qualifies it for Vulnerable status.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
Following taxonomic revision, the distribution of this European endemic species is now restricted to Apennine Italy (south to Calabria and part of the Salento Peninsula in Apulia), the extreme south of Switzerland (south of the Alps), the alpine regions of Austria, adjacent extreme southeastern Germany, southern Czechia, and western Hungary, south through Austria to Slovenia, Croatia, and western Bosnia-Herzegovina. The species occurs from sea level to elevations approaching 2,000 m asl.

There are a number of introduced subpopulations in western Switzerland (Geneva), Germany (not mapped), Portugal (São Miguel Island in the Azores), the Netherlands (not mapped), France (not mapped) and the UK (not mapped), however, the introduction pathway has not been confirmed.

This species was previously considered to occur through most of Italy, southern Switzerland, Slovenia, northern Croatia, and northern Bosnia-Herzegovina, with an apparently disjunct population on the Adriatic side of the Balkan Peninsula (in eastern Bosnia-Herzegovina, Serbia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Albania, south to central Greece), and with subpopulations north of the Alps in Austria, southeast Bavaria (Germany), western Hungary, and southern Czechia. However, following the recognition of Triturus macedonicus, subpopulations from eastern Bosnia-Herzegovina, western, central and southern Serbia, Montenegro, central and western North Macedonia and Albania to northeastern Bulgaria (the latter not included in the previously assessed concept of this species), south into northwestern and central Greece; northwestern Anatolian Türkiye have now been reassigned. Moreover, subpopulations from central and part of southeastern Serbia are now recognized as Triturus ivanbureschi.

Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)

This European endemic species is listed as Vulnerable (A3ce) both globally and for the EU27 Member States due to a projected population decline, estimated to be more than 30% over the next 15–30 years (which represents three generation lengths), from the potential impact of Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) on this species, and ongoing habitat loss and degradation that is occurring throughout its range.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is sensitive to declines in water quality. The principal threats to the species are the loss of aquatic habitats, especially breeding sites, through agricultural intensification and agrochemical pollution, and the introduction of predatory fishes. The species is also threatened by the loss of terrestrial habitats as a result of their transformation into arable land, reforestation, urban development, and transportation infrastructure development that increases mortality on roads (Silero et al. 2019). In Slovenia, project LIFE AMPHICON (LIFE18 NAT/SI/000711) aims to mitigate four road sections for the species by the end of 2024. Moreover, major declines have occurred in the lowlands of Italy due to the impact of invasive fish and crayfish (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019; Falaschi et al. 2021, 2022). In the Balkans, there has been a loss of breeding habitats in recent years due to decreased spring rains, perhaps as a result of global climate change. The use of the species as bait by fishermen (A. Romano pers. comm. October 2022) is unlikely to be a significant threat.

Ranavirus was detected on the species in Hungary (Vörös et al. 2020).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present, Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal demonstrate susceptibility to the disease for this species, with mortality observed in those individuals tested (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). On a precautionary basis, it is thought that it is unlikely that wild subpopulations would have much resistance to Bsal and it is considered to be a possible threat to this species. There are no current records of Bsal within this species range, however, it should be monitored if an outbreak occurs. Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be between 10–20 km per year. Due to the proximity of its range to multiple Bsal outbreaks, modelling (see attached Supplementary Information) has found this species to be at significant risk from Bsal in the next 15–30 years (which represents three generations). However, this does not take into account further human-induced introduction of the disease and should new outbreaks occur within this species’ range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: The species is occasionally used as bait by fishermen (A. Romano pers. comm. October 2022). There are no records of this species being utilized, although escape/accidental introduction from the pet trade has been suggested as the origin of the introduced subpopulations (AmphibiaWeb 2021).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas and several Natura 2000 sites. Prior to being considered a separate species, Speleomantes strinatii was listed on both Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, under S. italicus. 

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Although this species is not considered to be declining in Italy, further information is needed on the status of the subpopulations in France. A genetic study would allow for evaluation of the conservation status of the French subpopulations and to identify the most isolated ones in order to prioritise conservation actions (J. Renet pers. comm. November 2021). If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is found in the vicinity of streams and seepages, and amongst rocky outcrops and caves in mountainous areas. It can be found in traditionally managed village rural areas, but will not tolerate high levels of habitat destruction (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). It reproduces through the direct development of a few terrestrial eggs.

Generation length is estimated to be between 5–10 years.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is locally abundant in suitable sites and regularly recorded in surveys in Italy, including in a lot of historical localities. It is not considered to be declining in Italy. Recent surveys of the French range have shown that it is less abundant than within the Italian range (Renet et al. 2012). In France, it is less abundant in the western part of its global distribution, and this may be because it appears to be more difficult to observe, especially west of the Var river (Renet et al. 2012; J. Renet pers. comm. November 2021). It was historically recorded in Monaco with the first record in 1905, but no additional records have been made in the last 50 years although it is unknown what the survey effort has been (F. Ficetola pers. comm. September 2019). Due to almost all natural environments having been destroyed in the country, caused by urbanisation, it is thought to be unlikely that any individuals of the species have survived (J. Renet pers. comm. November 2021). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be locally decreasing.

The disease chytridiomycosis caused by Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging concern for salamanders in Europe (see Threats section). Extinction risk modelling for Bsal calculated the probability of extinction of the species in five generations based on a best and worse case scenario (see model in attached Supplementary Information). The best case scenario was calculated using the minimum generation length estimate and the worst case scenario using the maximum generation length estimate. For this species the probability of extinction for the best scenario using a generation length of five years is 3.65%, and for the worst scenario using a generation length of 10 years is 98.83%.

Applying criterion E, and using the midpoint of the range in probability of extinction from the extinction risk modelling (see link to spreadsheet in attached Supplementary Information), this species qualifies for Endangered, as it has a greater than 20% probability of extinction in the wild in five generations.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This European endemic species is restricted to southeastern France and northwestern Italy, from sea level to around 2,500 m asl. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 17,290 km2.

There are also two originally introduced and now viable subpopulations in France - one that was introduced to an old mine gallery in Ariège in the French Pyrenees in 1965, and the other which was discovered in 2015 at Angles-sur-l’Anglin, more than 500 km outside its known range (Lucente et al. 2016). These introduced subpopulations are not included within the distribution map.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Endangered because extinction risk modelling for Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) indicates that the probability of extinction for this species will be >20% in the next five generation lengths (25–50 years) [see attached Supplementary Information].
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
There is localised loss of habitat due to logging, tourist developments and urbanisation, as well as some localised disturbance by tourism in Italy (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). Climate change is likely to be a major threat to this species due to narrow microclimatic preferences of the genus, which will be problematic as the climate alters their distribution and activity in the future (E. Lunghi pers. comm. October 2021).

PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
It is generally common within its limited range. The eastern subpopulations of this species belong to a different genetic clade, Speleomantes ambrosii bianchii, which is largely introgressed with S. italicus. The western and eastern subpopulations are divided into two different subspecies, with no suitable habitat in between (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). The eastern side is considered to be abundant, and it is found in good numbers on the western side (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
